text: Great fish fry.  The fish is fresh and comes in a great portion size.  Service is good.  Having left the area, I really miss this place.
Crowded and awesome. Just imagine TGI's food, better prepared with a cold microbrew.
Best customer service, and they have everything.

i was hesitant about giving a car dealership 5 stars but really, i have had a fantastic experience here. i would most certainly recommend anyone to come here for a car (if they wanted a mazda or a vw)

here is how it went: my jag broke the rear driver's side ball joint. again. the friday before last. so mis and i went car shopping as i finally reached the point of not liking pouring money into a car more than i loved driving a car. 

we went to Northway Toyota first, our sales rep was nice and not too pushy but after trying the rav4 (didn't like it. the car was boring.) and sitting in the uber-cool FJ cruiser. (way too boxy, much less cool on the inside than on the out) and wanting to try the bug, it wouldn't start, battery was dead. so we went on...

i had searched online for a vehicle and found a really good deal at Martin Neemer for a honda element so we decided to go there next to try it out. turns out the owner took it home with him. the rep was apologetic about it but still, a car they listed online was not on the lot. i was irritated.

next we went to keeler, the mini dealership they didn't even acknowledge us until we went and said hello. i loved the mini but they didn't have any very good deals so we went to the honda part. there i tried an element (orange) and it was fine but the rep was really over the top and off-putting. so we decided to call it a day.

missy's husband adam had looked online and found some good deals on bugs at Cooley in East Greenbush tho so we decided to swing by on our way back. 

they were closed when we got there but we still walked around looking for the green one he had found online. out back we found it, it was unlocked so we got in and checked it out. i was instantly in love.  as we were walking back to the car, a young man came out and asked if he could help us. he was willing to go over information even tho it was a friday and they had closed 30 minutes earlier. i let him off the hook and said that i was interested but would come back monday.

to make this long story short, they gave me a great deal on it, less than the listed price on bluebook.com, they gave me money for the tradein on the jag, they gave me a loaner until the bug (that they had just gotten in) was ready for me. and they were Very friendly and helpful the entire time. 

this is the place to go for good service.

to

Excellent, excellent, excellent! Service is wonderful and so friendly, the food is fresh and very tasty and it comes out fresh and hot. Nothing is overspiced to be overdone and it is well seasoned. Everything goes perfectly with a mango milkshake.

Highly suggest the lamb madras...if you like coconut and nuts mixed into a cream sauce, it's perfect. It's the right blend of tangy meets spicey. That with some rice and side of naan and a potato samosa to start and you could have a happy stomach!

I really like Karavalli. Fresh, deliciously spiced food, the only down side is the price tag. If it were a few dollars cheaper I could bump them up to five, but then again I'm sure their quality would suffer. 

Even their buffets are amazing. Not just leftovers or generic food. I've tried so many dishes I've never even seen on the menus of other places on the lunch buffet at Karavalli.

The pizza is the best in Troy, period.  Don't give me any nonsense about how much you like the Buffalo Chicken at I Love Pizza of Troy.  

I will begin by saying that I am extremely picky about my pizza.  I have noticed that people from other parts of the world different from New Haven county in CT have no idea what good pizza is.  DeFazio's is not that great, but the best in Troy.  

I judge pizza on two main areas: crust and sauce.  If you hold toppings and cheese constant (RPI student here), the sauce and crust determines the quality of the pizza.  The crust is not that good.  It could be much thinner and have much more flavor.  A good Extra Virgin Olive Oil and a little more salt on the crust before the sauce and toppings could solve this problem.  

The sauce is really, really good.  It is a rustic sauce, not sweet just full of flavor.  They make their own delicious sausage.  They use high quality pepperoni.  They love food there and it shows.  They take pride in their family heritage and are very welcoming.  Plan on take-out.  There are only four small tables in the restaurant.  My friend went there only a few times to pick up pizza and they already knew his name.  

I really like this place, but the pizza could in fact be better.  I never had anything but pizza so I cannot comment on the remaining menu items.

Stopped in for a beer.  Sat on the patio and had an insipid porter and a bland IPA.  The wafting stench from something that must have been dead and rotting on the river bank below didn't help.  Beer reminded me of what you'd get at a "brewpub" run by AB or CoorsMolson.

I'm not one who easily throws out five stars.  And I'm not about to say that my lunch at The Flying Chicken was perfect.  But here we are, a few days later, and I still can't get the thought of the chicken and waffles at The Flying Chicken out of my head.  

The chicken and waffles comes with a plump waffle and two boneless, fried chicken breasts.  I also got a generous side of real maple syrup for a dollar extra, bringing the total for the meal to a grand $8.  It's always a risk getting boneless white meat at a fried chicken place; will it be as juicy as the dark meat?  

The Flying Chicken got it spot-on.  The chicken was moist and succulent on the inside.  The breading was crispy, drained properly, and filled with salt, pepper, and other spices that gave it a good kick.  K had a couple pieces of dark meat, and those were also done just right.  (I also wanted to steal her whole biscuit--there was something delectable, a touch of cheese, maybe, about it.)

I don't know how much one can say about a waffle, but this one deserves to be talked about.  Firm on the outside, and so fluffy and almost creamy inside.  It was excellent on its own with the maple syrup, but when you ate all three things in tandem, every bite was luxurious--sweet and rich and salty, crispy and fluffy all at the same time.

Now, I will say that K's collard greens didn't stack up to others I've had in the past.  They're made without meat, and so they were missing some richness and smokiness.  That could work, but I think the tang from the vinegar would need to be increased.  And the kitchen-sink cookie, while very enticing with marshmallow and pieces of bacon involved, didn't taste all that fresh.

No matter.  I'm still floating on their waffle while daydreaming about the fried chicken, so it's pretty much all happy thoughts over here.
Clean, the people are nice, and the meat prices are less expensive. Compared to Price Chopper's prices, they're a little cheaper.
Not good very thick crust tasteless red sauce no atmosphere would not recamend

They are one of the businesses out there that makes money on shipping. I order some touch up bottles from them. I ship all the time so I know UPS charges them about $11 to ship it. They charged me $28.07. Also they will not tell you the status of your order, if it's been shipped, or if there's any problem until you contact them. Absolutely poor customer service. They sell the bottles that I need. I've been looking and nobody else has them for sale. I wish there was another option because I hate ordering from these people.

When you are born and raised in Albany, Price Chopper and Hannaford are the only two grocery stores that really come to mind. A few years ago when Fresh Market announced they were making an entrance into the capital district I couldn't believe it.

Having shopped at Trader Joes a few times out of state, I was hoping Fresh Market could bring some of the same qualities and selections. The store is quite small, compared to others, but contains almost everything most stores have. 

One of the main reasons I shop at Fresh Market is for fresh beef. Fresh Market carries Hereford beef which is known for being leaner and more flavorful compared to most beef. The full service butcher counter carries it all from filet to chimichurri skirt steak to premade gourmet burgers and much more. Every time I have purchased beef here it has been amazing and tasty.

Fresh Market also has very good prepared foods. I have recently fallen in love with the curry chicken salad (thanks for the recommendation ;-)) and the baked potato salad is very good as well. They offer many other prepared foods such as fried and grilled chicken cutlets, meatballs, salads, and twice baked potatoes which I have heard are good. 

Other unique features are that you can grind your own fresh peanut butter as well as create your own 6 packs of beer, which is nice.

Fresh Market can be a little more expensive than other places but if you are looking for quality items and don't mind the increase then this is the place to shop.

This is a very nice place. If you like crowd and noise, downstair by the bar is the place for you. On the other hand, second floor in the Trojan room is surprisingly quiet. Food is the usual, but good portion for the price. Beer is cheap too if you're from NYC. 

If you'll be there during daylight, river view is great too. The place is between the main 2 bridges of Troy.

When I first found Lee Lin i thought their food was amazing, but I think it was really was just because it wasn't as horrible as most other chinese places. After having some real chinese food, I still think the food is ok, (for delivery at least). I like the sesame chicken has a real sesame taste to it, and that you can order mild, medium, hot, etc. 

The problem I have and was reminded of it tonight is the insanely inconsistent delivery. At first there would be times they would come in 15 minutes and I didn't even know how they could have cooked the food that fast. I would give solid tips, i am always a real solid tipper, i would tip 10 bucks on a 30 dollar bill if it came in 15 minutes.

The last 2 times i have ordered the food has taken 1.5 hours to 2 hours to arrive and i have had to call both times. Today I called 1.5 hours after ordering and was told the driver had just left. After I had given specific directions for the driver he still had to call. 

I feel bad for the driver, I know it probably wasnt his fault. But I want to send a message so I tipped nothing, and told him, "I had a better tip for you 2 hours ago sorry".

So if you guys ever do happen to read this, if your driver is coming back pissed off that he got no tip, or  you consistently are getting so busy that you cant deliver food within 2 hours, then it is time for you to shell out some cash and get an extra driver.  

Or at least have the experience to tell us it is going to be a while, or call us back. Don't tell me it is going to be a half hour and set my expectations high by being good some times and then be the complete opposite the next time.

The beer here was GREAT!  Try the whiskey porter...it is fabulous!  

I enjoyed the house burger and my mother had the grilled chicken sandwich.  The BBQ sauce on the chicken sandwich was great.  It was marinated in the cherry raspberry beer.  

The service was great and the atmosphere was even better.  Try out this beer!

Information about products on their website is incorrect.  They shipped the product but it wasn't what was listed on their website.  Customer service refuses to refund even when the error was made by them.  Poor customer service!

Now that my puppy love stage with The Fresh Market is over I feel that it's fair to review it.

We'll start with what sent me in to my blissful denial stage. 

When you walk in, the smell of fresh flowers and the classical music immediately put you in a great mood.
It's a fantastic way to start off a shopping trip. (not so good for my wallet) 
Everything is beautifully laid out and merchandised wonderfully. 

You sometimes you forget you're in Latham.

(Although the zen like shopping trip are null and void when you go on a Saturday)  

The merchandise-  

The orange juice is super delicious but pretty pricey.   They used to have a sample area for it but that has since disappeared.

I heart the coffee and all of the coffee choices. My favorite is the chocolate cherry.   It's actually cheaper than the Green Mountain that I usually buy. 
I also love that I can get a little sample of coffee to have while shopping.

Spices!  I love the little spice bags I can pick up for 1-3 bucks on average.   I can fill up my spice collection without breaking the bank.

Notable mentions-The ginormous olive bar, the fact that they carry hearts of palm (although none from Brazil)  and the set price for the you pick 6 beers.
The sun dried tomato and asaigo cheese bread.

Excuse me for a second.
ahhhhhhhhhhhhhhh mmmmmmmmmm

Okay, I'm back. 

Now onto the reality stage of the relationship.

Besides the already mentioned poor cheese selection, the bread selection is probably worse.

Since they don't seem to carry the Ezekiel bread I usually buy, I was going to treat myself to regular old wheat bread but after scouring the small bread section I couldn't find anything that wasn't filled with gross ingredients.  
Also, I don't think they carry almond milk.

Now for the embarrassing part.   
In a moment of starved weakness I purchased a spicy trio sushi platter.  It was pretty gross all around but what do you expect?  However, it gets worse.  As I was stuffing a piece in my mouth I looked over and and staring back at me was a piece of shrimp that was not de-turded.  (I'm no seafood expert but I have seen Tommy Boy a number of times.)
Let me say, I didn't finish my mouthful.  

That was hard for me to admit but I felt it was necessary to save someone else from making my mistake. 

I still love The Fresh Market as a fun little excursion and a place to get coffee but not as my regular shopping place.

Another reviewer said "cute retro-vibe" and I'm reminded of the 75+ year old lady who told me, as she slowly ate her burger and fries, how she had been coming to Jack's ever since she was a little girl....  Retro, indeed.

Retro is when you make something now that reflects something from the past.  Jack's, in my opinion, -is- the past.  Let me explain....

I'm vegan now and wouldn't actually eat at Jack's today, but I ate there on and off for decades.  I still crave these burgers and fries, and I haven't had them since the Summer of 2008.  That's a long time for a craving to stick around.  There has to be a reason....

1)  I'm pretty sure I started eating at Jack's when I was in diapers, and although I can't remember what I had for lunch today, I can tell you that Jack's food simply hasn't changed.  Consistency.  You aren't going to Jack's for something modern, off-the-wall, different - it's an establishment where, unlike many others, you know exactly what you're going to get each and every time you order.  You also know that if you come back the next day, or the next year, there's a pretty good chance you won't be saying "this used to be different" or "they changed something, I can't quite put my finger on it!"  In a world where things are constantly being watered-down, and change is the only constant, Jack's is an oasis of...well, tasty-tasty grease.

2)  The menu is simple: You've got your basic hamburger with a grilled bun and grilled onions.  I love caramelized onions, and whenever I make them at home, I pray that I will eventually hit the jackpot and figure out their secret.  Yes, grease from hamburger -might- help, but it hadn't in the past, and as a vegan, I'm only going to get so close now.  Hot dogs are probably good but...they're hot dogs.  You've got your fries, which are pretty tasty, although best eaten hot with ketchup (if you're into that).  They have milk, milkshakes, and soft drinks (fizzy and not).  I used to get two or three burgers, a large fry and a Hawaiian Punch.  Pretty sure I slept the drive home each and every time.  

3)  No-frills.  You pull up, park - plenty of parking - and wait in line.  You order, and they fill your order quickly.  The menu is so small, it's not that hard to choose, and they don't really have to spend a lot of time making different things.  You want a burger or hot dog?  Fries with that?  Maybe a drink?  Done.  You take your order on the red tray over to the picnic tables and pray that your napkins or food don't blow away if the wind is high.  That's what the drink is for anyway - to keep the napkins down, and to wash things down.

4)  Alfresco!  How often do we actually eat outside, on a picnic table, under beautiful trees filtering the sunlight?  I'd say for most of us staring at our computer monitors reading this review, not often enough.  Leave your technological gadgets in the car and have a meal the way it used to be.  It's really pretty, even when it's warm in the summer, because of the huge...HUGE shade trees.

A few things to keep in mind:

* This place is easy to miss.  You turn a corner, from either direction, and you're like "whoa!"  If you have a GPS, and it takes kindly to the lack of sky visibility, or if you have directions pre-printed, you're golden.  If you pass it, turn around - it's worth it. 

* Go hungry.  I mean, seriously, you want to eat at least one burger and a basket of fries.  If you go, and you're not hungry, you will be sad.

* Don't compare.  This place has been around longer than most of the people writing reviews on Yelp.  It's older than the Internet and, heck, it's most likely older than TV.  It's nice to see a good business sticking around for what must seem like forever in this economy and, if you think about it, Jack's has survived a lot worse. If anything, Jack's is a living testament  to what you can do, and what you can keep going, with a good, simple business strategy, and people wiling to come to work every day.  This is not a fancy restaurant, and the prices are reasonable.  I think a lot of the ingredients we see in foods these days weren't even invented when Jack's first opened up, so keep things in perspective.

* Bring a friend.  Hey, someone has to drive your sleepy butt home, right?  Or at least talk to you to keep you awake while you drive.

Also, I have seen many times where people have stated that it's a cash-only establishment.  Do yourself a favor and call ahead. If they do take credit cards, you can save yourself a trip to the ATM. Or just go retro and pay cash - it's fun.

Summary: I don't believe you can get this burger experience anywhere else, and I've tried.

Jacks: I can feel my arteries hardening just thinking about it!
Great sliders with a unique taste! I go here for lunch at least once a month

yes, i know it is a chain. but it is a good chain. 

there is a ton of seating, the service is friendly and good and they have a Very nice salad bar that comes with the meals. the SB has such things as oriental cabbage salads, lentil sprouts, tons of veggies including peas and some good dressings (i like the house, it is a sort of dillish type.) and they have extras to put on top like soy nuts, granola, wasabi peas, almonds, raisins and those asian noodles my daughter likes so much.

they serve a delicious brown bread to start you with (there is fresh french for kids if you ask for it tho it takes them time, as they have to make that individually). there drinks are reasonalby priced and sized and they have a good selection of top shelf liquors (for our martinis). their steak is always good. butter knife cut good. one of the things that irritates me however is that you only get a starch with your meal. you cannot ask for veggies instead. but whatever, you can get a nice size side of fresh steamed asparagus or broccoli so i just suck it up.

the decor is typical of a chain steak house, with fake deer heads and stuffed bears along with the somewhat Western motif.

this is one of my daughter's favorite places and never fails to satisfy (that is as long as you stay away from the Non steak items. the shrimp was awful and so was the trout. i suppose the lobster is fine as they proudly show them on the left when you come in.)

Pros:
* The food is great!
   * Dosas
   * Bhel poori
   * Biryani 
   * Saag paneer
* The restaurant is generally clean with good dinnerware, etc.

Cons:
* The service is thoroughly inept. 
    * Expect to ask several times for items.
    * And make EXTRA certain they understood you.
    * Chances are they'll still get it wrong.

As an apparent law of nature, all central Asian restaurants have abysmal service, but this one at least is clean, uses real dishware, and really does serve excellent dinner.

Went to the Ilium Cafe in Troy tonight. Everything about it was fantastic, especially the waitstaff. From the hostess to the waiter, great customer service. I had the talapia, wow excellent! My daughter had the filet mignon and she loved it!  My wife had the shrimp and angel hair, yummy. The Bailey cheesecake, OMG, to die for. Marla and her staff have a very creative and tasty menu, and I will return very soon. Thanks Marla

The best Indian in the area- and it's really not close- for not only the quality of the food but the variety.  

This isn't just a slather it in curry Americanized northern Indian place; they specialize in southern Indian cuisine.  

I can't recommend this enough- go there and experiment  try something you've haven't before- it will be good. The brunch buffet is always a delicious treat.

Wow, this place has everything you need. It also employes people who know exactly what almost all the beers taste like and how they are made. I have no idea what half the words they say mean, but they usually can pick out a great beer. They have lots of good beers to try, and all of the usual and classic favorites for a good price.

This has to be my most favorite beer store in the world.
I LOVE this place.  The staff is very friendly and they do great nails.  I love the atmosphere.  Stephen and Nikki are great people and they have created a very friendly atmosphere.

Frosty Magoo's is easily the worst name ever for a bar, but this is one of the best and most eccentric nightspots in the area. Good luck finding this place, though. They have no web presence, there's no identifying signage other than a chalkboard panel at the door, they're on a street that Google's street view doesn't cover, and I'm not even sure if they advertise. Just wander around River Street near First and ask around.

FM's in a former bank. There's a small plaque on the building stating it was built in 1811. The high-ceilinged interior of the main bar is decorated with junk salvaged from the alley behind the building. Overall, the design feel is "That looks good enough, fuck it, I'm done."  The walk-in safe is carpeted with astroturf, and people seem to use the room as a putting green. There's an alcove for darts, a back patio full of people making out, some dead space with mismatched tables, and a small stage adjoining a kitchen. The waitresses have to carry their orders though the bands as they perform.

Clientele is a stew of Trojans. Everyone's drunk, and everyone is having fun.

I love this place. Their pizza and other food is always really good and cooked on time. They have great service and I love the online deals and rewards club. I have gotten 5 or more free pizzas from them in the last couple years because of winning them as prizes or using my rewards points. The only bad thing is that they don't deliver to my house, even though I only live 5 miles away.

Great pizza at a great price!  It is an average pizza place but the prices are so reasonable!  

I give it 5 stars because it is fast, cheap and delicious!  YUMMY!

I bought  a car from them 2 years ago. They were pretty good and the sales person understood that I knew what I want.  He didn't try to sell me anything I wasn't interested in.  i even got some free Mazda schwag.

Today I got a birthday card from them.  2 years and a new state later and they still bothered to send me a happy birthday note.
That deserves a review!

Do not trust the hype, fellow RPI students. I firmly believe that you have to be 100% hammered to be able to enjoy this "food." 

Bella is some of the worst food you will ever be tricked into paying money for. It is awful. It's greasy as all hell, the crust is flavorless and stale, and the toppings are legitimately disgusting. They are all either super salty or just gross in general. The sausage in particular forced me to throw out like 80% of my slice, which is something I would never do to a slice of pizza under other circumstances.

The only reason this place is popular is that it's open stupidly late and it's really cheap. But do yourself a favor and order Domino's to eat a little later so you don't have to subject yourself to this nest of mediocrity.

I've had better food from Commons. I've had better food for 50 shillings in a rural village in Kenya. Do not eat here. I'd rather starve.

Their 8 cut is considered a large and cost only $10.95 and it's huge. 
Apparently their the 1st place winner at the Watervliet Wing War, but I haven't tried their wings yet.
They have soup of the day, salads, cold and hot subs, pastas, burgers. They also Cater.

Absolutely delicious! I've eaten here many times and it's a favorite for lunch takeout in our office. The food is always fresh, always tasty, and the service is great too. I appreciate that the menu options range from the staples to more interesting and adventurous foods. Their falafel are some of the best I've ever had. My husband said their gyros rival Anton's and that's certainly a compliment. I've never been disappointed and will continue to head to the Garlic Lovers regularly!

I was meeting a friend and Browns happened to be convenient. I got there and there was ample parking (a huge relief after the snow storm) and went right inside. I had been looking at the menu earlier in the day... because I do indeed research my food options beforehand, and was disappointed with what was listed. Considering Browns is mostly restaurant and only 1/8 of the space is actually bar you'd think their menu would reflect that. I wasn't in the mood for a burger (this is indeed very rare... no pun intended) and everything else just looked eh. 

I ended up just choosing the Southwest wrap because it was the least offensive and I thought that it'd be difficult to screw up a wrap... I was wrong. I asked for no cheese, which they did properly, but the wrap was kind of empty and open on each end (huge pet peeve) so everything was falling out and I had dressing all down my arm. Real attractive when you're eating with another human being. I ended up not even attempting the other half, and crunched on the over-fried fries. 

If I weren't driving home, then perhaps a draft would have made everything ok, but if you're going to serve food, make sure it's good. Browns, I will not be back.

This is definitely my favorite local music venue. It's spacious with wood floors, high ceilings, two levels and a large stage. And - you get the added bonus of it being right next door to Brown's Brew Pub so they serve Brown's awesome beers. 

The last show I saw here was Ted Leo and the Pharmacists with Georgie James. The sound was great and you could actually move around a little without feeling completely claustrophobia. Parking is easy too, because there's a municipal lot next door.  

They sometimes hold the post-Troy Night Out music events here and those are always a lot of fun too. 

It also seems like the music schedule is getting a lot more - it used to be mainly just jam band and blues-types of stuff, but now they seem to really be mixing it up.

Browns is very solid. Came here for my friend's 21st birthday dinner (she went to RPI) in August of 2010.

I can't remember what beer I got -- it was either Oatmeal Stout or Cherry Raspberry (a friend got one and I got the other and I think we split them). Both were excellent and I've heard great things about the other brews as well.

Chicken wings were great -- deep-fried, super crispy. I normally prefer non-breaded wings but these were so good I didn't mind. I split a dozen with a friend and we also tried chicken spiedies, which were good.

Overall, I'd come back. I think I'd have to come here more than once to give it more stars.

I discovered this place through my father. Every Thursday he heads over to 'Golden for "Polish Night" and brings plenty of things from there to nibble on. I'm not sure if Thursday is the only night they have the Polish food, but that's the night that's been dubbed Polish Night.

The food? Uum, pretty tasty :) We're Ukrainians(I'm half.. papa and gram are full).. not in fact Polish but I guess we all kinda share the same food so I've grown up on it ,and think I'm a fair judge of  the "Slavic" eats lol. 

The Golumpkies(stuffed cabbage) are very good... like very, very good.  I myself don't eat the cabbage part.. tried it once when I was like 5 or 6 and once was enough. Even as an adult, I still have a childish palate towards the veggies. That's why you'll find veg in vitamin form in my medicine cabinet! Anyhow, if you're like me and you ever have these and just eat the stuffing.. the stuffing is veddy, veddy good. Two thumbs up! Or if you're all brave and adult about it. and dig the cabbage you'll probably really enjoy the whole package. My father and grammy do and they're good judges on it.. it's def grammy approved.

The Kiebasi? I don't eat it but my father and grammy enjoy it.

The Pyrohy(pierogis)? They're tasty. Not Ukrainian Hall Bazzar style good(I'm biased).. but still quite tasty. There's a little more of a sauerkraut taste to them(it's just a hint I swear), which we like in our family. Funny, but this is the only time I like that stuff and didn't even know what it was when I tried these "what's the taste?" .. I was surprised I enjoyed it. Had I know what it was I probably wouldn't have tried it. Something about the potatoes, I think the fact they're not as thick of a texture as the ones I'm used to, keeps me from *loving* them.. but I do enjoy them plenty.  

If you were to go on a Thursday, you would see a ton of old-timers and plenty of "youngin's"  leaving with bags of stuff. That to me, says this place knows what they're doing :)

I guess this place used to be in Cohoes as the Golden Krust Bakery but they relocated here and downsized after a fire. They now have a smaller seating section(according to my dad it was much bigger in Cohoes) for dining in, and focus on Bagels and sandwiches most days. I'm not sure of prices, but I'm going to guess they're on the cheap eats side seeing it's got a large takeout base.

Stopped in mid-week for pizza. Ordered the garlic bread & the Kennedy pizza (can't remember its name). I didn't fall in love with the food--dry garlic bread, alright pizza, but it was a comfortable place to hang out. Low key, non-pretentious.

Well as everyone says, the bar area is packed beyond belief, especially if a live band is in the house - so opt for a table if you've got it.

The service can be weird though. We kept pointing to beers on the back of the regular menu only to hear that they were sold out (it was Friday night around 9pm...so that's weird). But eventually we settled on a few beers and (when given the right menu) got most of the beers on the menu. The beers are all flavorful and surprising, packing decent punches and spices, enough to satisfy a wide range of micro-beer lovers.

The food is also fantastic. I especially dig the pretzel and hot wings. The pretzel is served hot and fresh, with a delicious dipping mustard. The hot wings (went with the cherry ale finish) were sweet and salty, meaty, crisp, and served with delicious blue cheese.

Overall, outside of some shotty service, and some above average prices, I'd say this is a great spot to hang out with friends and catch up, drink a few great beers, and snack. Good stuff.

I've been shopping at the Homebrew Emporium in Cambridge for a few months now, and decided to stop by to the Rensselaer location while I was in town to pick up a few things. 

The store is SO HUGE compared to the one in Cambridge, but this comes as no surprise considering the cost of real estate in both locations. While the Rensselaer location has the disadvantage of being in a weird strip mall on a heavily trafficked road (it's hard to take a left turn into this place), that all doesn't matter once you step inside.

The selection of stock on the shelves is huge, there's almost an entire room dedicated to wine kits, unlike the single shelf at Cambridge. You could easily lose yourself browsing around at bottles, wine kits, corkers, presses, beer brewing ingredients, books, and miscellaneous accessories.

The employees were very helpful and were able to find me the things I needed very quickly, and they were also quite friendly. I was in and out quick because I was in a rush, but in the future I'd like to spend more time checking this place out.

I will start by saying that I was born in Poland so I had very high expectations of this place. And luckily when I walked in I was pleasantly surprised by the the notes of my spoken native language. This place is authentic as it gets because the family who runs it are actually Polish. 

I do not agree that the decor was ugly like some review it was surprisingly classy for a Polish eatery lol. 

The perogi were properly overstuffed and prepared with the fried onion bits like my Grandma and Ma used to make. And the potato pancakes were crunchy and perfect! They could have also been out of my Moms kitchen. The fried Nutela and banana crepes were also delicious even after transport (because we could not eat them there, we were so full, we took them home). DELICIOUS.

The people who sat next to us also looked like they had lovely food, it smelled amazing. Some kind of meat and pot pan stack that I need to come back and try.

The only thing which wasn't up to par was the spinach crepe which was overcooked, tasted ok. And they could have had more Polish beer varieties, but I'm hoping they do since they recently opened a beer garden.

The waitress was also lovely. She was very friendly. All my senses were telling me I was at home and well satisfied. As I walked out I thanked the lady of the house (in Polish) and told her we sure would be back.

Only regret is that it took me this long living in the capitol district to discover this place. A must to check out especially if you have a soft spot for perogi.

And no there is no S on the end !!! Perogi is both singular and plural. Enjoy!

After moving to Cohoes I was told Mick's was the best thing there and I had to try it. I don't know why I waited so long. I wasn't in the mood for regular pizza and they have a variety of specialty pies so I tried the Shrimp Scampi pizza. The white pizza is very good complete with a garlic seasoned crust but the shrimp were really tiny. Not that I expected anything a whole lot bigger because its just a pizza topping. No one else was interested in it so I just got a small for myself. It only takes about 2 slices to fill you up so I had plenty left over. This is the only reason I wouldn't try the Shrimp Scampi pizza again. I have to be in a certain mood to be craving it and shrimp isn't quite as good reheated. The wings were also surprisingly tasty. I ordered medium for myself which weren't hot but had great flavor instead. But I found myself getting addicted to the honey bbq wings my gf ordered. I thought the prices were very reasonable also. Good value for the money.

Call me old fashioned but when I order a pasta dish with something it in, I expect more than a trace. Such was the case with the pasta and smoked salmon dish. The such was good but the salmon was nearly invisible and the peas were missing.
My friend enjoyed her veggies lasagna and said it was delicious but I noted that it was brined around the edges. My other friend asked for a piece of salmon with her salad and it was over cooked and dry. For the total cost I was disappointed. Service was great but getting old looking match sticks of veggies in the salad plate and being skimpy with the pasta ingredients is inexcusable considering the price. No dish should ever come to the table overlooked or burned.

Pretzels, pretzels, pretzels!!!! They are fantastic here. The mustard sauce that comes with them is especially good. The burgers are also good, as is the Thai shrimp wrap. I'm not a beer connoisseur, so I can't speak to their brewing prowess. But, they have a serviceable wine list.

Also, Monday night trivia is very fun here.
Umm. I have no idea how this place is related to Lee Lin (a 5 * in my book). Food looked aweful and was barely edible. And for $30 for 2 people it's a complete rip off.
Portions are large and prices are fair. My favorite slice is the cheesesteak pizza, lots of tasty meat and onions.

my bf get my a gift card for 90 min massage here and i went there this morning. i feel soo relax from daily research. ya i m a super nerdy phd!

the room is super small which surprise but the lady is pretty nice and i enjoyed it a lot! i am looking forward to come back. 

it is kind of my first massage experience in the US and i 'd like try other places.

Terrible service.  I ordered two gyros for take-out today.  I arrived and he said they only prepared one for me.  He said that he would make another one (without apologizing) and that it would take ten minutes.  I needed to get to work, so I was short on time.  About five minutes later, I asked how long it would be and he said ten minutes again.  I told him that I was in a rush and I would not be able to purchase them still.  He said 'So you're canceling?' and walked away.

Pre-ordered our Thanksgiving meal on Sunday.  Called early today to confirm our order.  My husband just went to pick it up, and they are "out" of gravy......How the hell does that happen?  And for such an essential part of a holiday meal?  Apparently we have a different interpretation of the word "order" than the Fresh Market does. For us, "order" means, "set aside for our exclusive purchase," not, "hey dude, if we happen to have it around, you can like, totally buy it." Not acceptable.  Mind blown.
Great service. Great food options. Adequate seating. Closes in the afternoon (boo!).
Been here a bunch of times and I have never been disappointed.

My husband and I were married on a Saturday afternoon and were looking for a "post-wedding" hangout for our friends and family. My husband's family went here on the suggestion of our hotel and were settled in upstairs when we arrived with a few friends.

When we asked if we could sit with our family upstairs, we were told that "service was closed" on the top floor. We explained politely that we knew our family was up there, as we had just spoken with them.

The hostess (middle-aged, curly hair, black dress) got very snippy with us and looked aghast that we would even SUGGEST that there were people being seated up there. "I don't know what you're talking about, it's not my problem". We even tried explaining that we were just married and wanted to see our family. No-go, we weren't allowed up.

Fine, we said we could then sit downstairs on our own, which was EMPTY. There were 8 of us, and they could have easily put two tables together to accommodate us. Apparently, that was too difficult, so we left and went down the street to the Irish-Mexican place that was great and very friendly.

As a girl from upstate New York hosting visitors from Long Island and New York City, I was hoping that I could show them some "Upstate hospitality", and not be treated snootily with such scorn. Sadly, Browns Brewing could not provide this.

Our family stopped by on our way home from skiing in Vermont. It was a great little side trip and while it didn't take very long to get there once off the beaten path (about 5 minutes) I was sure glad we had a GPS to help us get there.  The seating is very limited but luckily we got there and all the tables were open, but the advice of reserving a seat is probably a good one.

We had the pizza which was very good, but since I saw that they made their own sausage prominently displayed in the window, I made sure that I got a side dish of that as well. This is quite simply some of the best sweet Italian sausage that I have ever had. I was really glad that they had a grocery right next door so I could take some home. 

The pizza was very good and the sauce was fantastic and you can tell that they use very fresh ingredients. My only beef is one of personal tastes, as I prefer a thin crust and their pizzas are more on the medium thickness range. 

The owner and his son were both very friendly to me and my family and made us feel welcome.

I came here last night with my husband and some friends from work who raved about this place.  They were not joking, this pizza is awesome.  What I like the most is that you can substitute any of their pizzas with whole wheat crust.  I would highly recommend spending the extra dollar or two to do so.  The whole wheat crust adds a nice heartiness to the pizza, and hey, it's healthier!

We shared the puttanesca pizza, but we substituted pesto for the tomato sauce.  We also got the chicken and red roasted peppers pizza, and added some goat cheese to the top. Both pizzas were amazing.  And again, the whole wheat crust is so hearty that I felt like I was going to burst after having two slices.

Oh, and it's BYOB, so feel free to sit back with a glass of wine while enjoying this amazing pizza.  I'll be back!

I'm going to give it a 5 but say it s more of a 4.5 (I'm feeling generous and the bar tender did put the Yankees game on for us). 

The decor is of the variety of two wrongs make a right. Its dark and has all sorts of weird signage which makes it seem like its going for a dive feel, but then it has these cute little light fixtures and adorable CLEAN bathrooms with vintage magazine ad wall paper and a chalk board with an inspirational message, which say I'm a friendly neighborhood bar. But then they have 25 cent skee ball and I think I saw a Foosball table in one of the back rooms, which made me think is this "Dave & Busters". (ya see the place has a large L shaped main room with a raised platform and then 3 or 4 little rooms off the bottom part of the "L" for games like Ms. Pacman, Skeeball, and darts. I now know what to do on weekends when I'm bored: get a roll of quarters and work on mastering skee ball. 

My friend and I were actually drinking wine at FM's (we started with dinner around the corner and decided not to risk mixing). The wine was $5 a glass, CHEAP, but not cheap wine. I didn't see the label of what they were pouring (and by pouring I mean filling the glass to the brim) but it wasn't Yellow Tail or Little Penguin which seem to be the main labels I find in non-wine bars. 

The crowd was a little younger (than me). Mostly in their mid-twenties, so I felt a little old. It was a mix of RPI dorks, Sage girls, and a few dudes wearing MMA shirts. Nothing hostile or uninviting and even thought I felt like an old lady, I'll be back.

Loved the soft ice cream here!  I love going to drive-ins!  In Florida we do not have drive-ins like these.  The service was a little slow but i didn't mind because it was nice outside.  Have not had the food but I can say the ice cream was yummy!
Please don't come here.  I want to keep it a secret.....

5 staars because as it says, this is about as good as your going to get around here. Yes Cordonas is unbeatable but thats more itialian specialty, this is the closest thing we will probably ever see to a whole foods in this area. Down to the products, the crab dip is top notch, breads all nice and fresh, filet is actually good for supermarket standards. Cheese is a little pricey but well worth it if your a cheese head. Deserts are well priced and great. Fruits and flowers both very fresh. Somewhat of a suprise, the pre packaged sushi is actually pretty fresh. That's covers everything I have bought from here so far, will update Im sure.

Anyone who knows me knows I like my BBQ. So when I heard about Mustang in my new hometown, I had to try it out. I headed over there and the space is quite large, well kept, with lots of seating. Mustang's sign outside broadcasts BBQ and Fried Chicken. Now, they were already up against a powerhouse in Pig Pit BBQ just down the road, which I LOVE. But the fried chicken got me interested. I went in and ordered and half rack meal with sweet potato fries and corn bread, and two pieces of chicken; a breast and a leg. I got all this to go but made a point to try the fries as soon as I got out to my vehicle as the trip can sometimes make them soggy. I was sorely disappointed that the wide cut fries were not crisp, nor taste terribly fresh. I got home and set down to work...er, eat. I started right into the leg of fried chicken. It was good, but I was hoping for something that stood out. I'd rather go to Kennedy's or even Popeye's (yes, I said it) until I find someplace that knows how to do real fried chicken. Then came the ribs. This were pork baby backs and I thought them to be too saucy and too over cooked. the meat did fall off the bone, but I want a rib where the sauce is the icing on the cake, not the putty on the car. They do have plenty of sandwiches on the menu, and I may well go back to try a couple of other things on their menu, but they are going to have a hard time luring me from Pit Pit a second time.

Went here on a Sunday with some friends for a game of mini-golf. It's your typical well-landscaped course design, with a miniature mountain. Some holes of note are the one with three levels (hint: hit the ball into the middle hole on the top level and it will come rocketing out at the bottom level, skipping the second level entirely) and one with you have to hit the ball into a stream, which throws it onto another green. 19 holes altogether for $6.00. Good deal. Some holes are in the woods, so there's a lot of shade to relax in. And even on a Sunday afternoon, there was hardly anyone around to catch up behind us. They also have bumper boats, but those always have standing water in them, and you'll probably get typhoid fever if you sit in it.

We just went for the first time on Sunday afternoon and it was GREAT!!! Reasonable family fun; my 3 1/2 year old daughter loves the rides that you would see at the fair or on the boardwalk and this place has all of them (for a reasonable price).  The place is clean and friendly and I can't wait to go back.
the best indian food in the US ( I grew up in the SFO bay area , spent time in CT/NY and lived a while in India too ) !!!!

I went to brown's Taproom with my girlfriend last night and it was one of the best experiences I have had a restaurant in a while. What really stuck out were the wings. Our waitress helped us decide on what kind we should get and she suggested the BBQ that are kind of a fruit sounding sauce, the wings are dipped in mild sauce first. Wow! is all I can say. They were so good, probably the best wings I've ever had including my own and I consider my own wings to be top notch. They had great beer, not extraordinary but very good. The burgers were great and the staff was excellent. I left a hefty tip in kind but to be honest we wanted to kiss the waitress for the wings they were so good. Excellent meal I will be going back this week before I head back to Iraq. That's a meal I want to remember.

I have never eaten a thing at Browns Brewing Company but I gave it four stars anyway for one reason, the Whiskey Porter.  Oh my god this is one of the most delicious beers I have ever had.  Its dark, rich and strong... REAL strong.

The menu sounds kind of good and they have a few vegan options so one of these days I might go back and eat something.

This place is great and the staff is excellent.  Chatted with my friend and me about Midwestern breweries and gave us an honest assessment of local capital district brews.  They even have a few beers on tap which he let us try.  The only hang up was that I was looking for a sour flemish ale or something similar and they didn't have anything, but they do have a nice selection of European beers otherwise.

Based on the many great reviews of this restaurant my wife, son and I ventured across the Husdon to check it out.  Our experience was mixed.  We started with crab cakes and the soup special (red lentil).  The soup was excellent but the crab cakes were inconsistent.  The crab cakes were presented with a nice sauce, but one of the two cakes was significantly less crispy (under done) than the second one.  Next up were good salads with a nice house dressing.  For our main meal, I had the special that featured seafood ravioli.  My meal was excellent.  My wife had the scallop dish which was well prepared, but had a slight "fishy" taste.  Not the hallmark of excellent shellfish.  My son had the kid's cheeseburger.  The server didn't ask how he had wanted the burger and I guess the default was very well done.  Our server mentioned pita would be on the way, but it didn't show up until much later in the meal after we asked about it.  All in all an ok meal, but I can't imagine making the 1/2 hour drive anytime soon.

$35 for a french pedicure.  It was okay.  The massage chair was nice but had a mind of its own.  I didn't really chat much with the fella doing my pedicure, but he seemed really focused.  He spent a lot of time making sure the white lines were even on both feet.  All in all it was a satisfactory job and I'd go back for a quick pedicure again (but not a pampering pedicure).  

Apparently this is the go to place for lots of Troy High girls.
Great Food!  Great Prices!  Best Pan Fried Dumplings I have ever eaten
Sadly, this place closed over the summer of 2009. RIP porky goodness.

Java ++ is more like 2 stars, but I'll bump them up a star for the deliciously free wifi.

The coffees are coffee shop priced (on the expensive side for anything that's not just a regular cup of joe). The food's overpriced and nothing to write home about or get excited over. 

Pros are that there are lots of outlets to plug your laptop into, and they take credit cards. Service is pretty friendly if a little chatty at times.

Cons are that it's not really that quiet. There's a large TV in the store, and when people turn it up it can get loud. Bring headphones and it's not that big of a problem, just an annoyance if you're doing something that requires concentration. This is more of a socializing place than a studying kind of place.

I'm bummed they're only open until about 7 pm most nights, though! I thought since they were by RPI they'd be open late, but for me 7 pm is an early closing time. If I want a later coffee shop to hit up in Troy, it's Flavor's downtown, unfortch. Because of this, I probably won't be back just because I'm only there for about 45 minutes before it's time to head out. Not much of an incentive to choose this over a library or just staying at home for me.

I had gotten a gift certificate here for Christmas but never used it until tonight.

I had the pan bronzed halibut, which was nicely cooked. It was served with a small portion of fava beans and some lobster risotto, along with a few "frizzled" grape tomatoes (they tasted poached to me.) The risotto was tasty if a bit salty, and only one chunk of lobster meat. I wish there'd been a few more fava beans and tomatoes. Why are high end restaurants so skimpy on the veggies? I love vegetables so come on, stop being so stingy. It was a good dish, but not great, and the portion was on the small side. I forgotten what the sauce was, as it was very light and barely noticeable. That dish was 32 dollars.

My boy wasn't into his delmonico buffalo ribeye steak with roquefort mashed potatoes, grilled veggies and Newcastle beer-battered onion rings. In fact, he didn't like any of it. He says the potatoes were bland, the meat was grisly and the onion rings were flavorless. 

The service however, was really great and they took that dinner off our bill without asking. I had the basmati rice pudding for dessert, which was very tasty and was more like a thick custard than a pudding. Did I mention the service was great and very professional? There was also a live pianist, making for a nice touch. 

The decor's nice for the most part, sort of upscale Mediterranean-style. 
I might give it another shot, but would avoid the buffalo special next time. My main issue is that for the prices here - at a restaurant in downtown Troy - I think the food should have been much better than it was... my halibut dish wasn't bad, but for $38, I think it should have been much better. I was also pretty hungry soon after and had to eat something soon after. My boy's dish was $42, and as described before, it was pretty disappointing.

I'm giving it two stars because the ambiance and service were so good, even if the food was grossly underwhelming.

I would absolutely recommend the Franklin Plaza to anyone looking to make their special occasion PERFECT. When my husband and I were looking for wedding venues in the Capital District, we were referred to The Franklin Plaza by a relative who had recently been to someone else's wedding there. He boasted about the food and how pretty the reception room was, so we decided to check it out (knowing that we had basically decided on another venue already). 

Since we live in NYC, we made a quick call to see if there was a way we would be able to come see the space that weekend. We spoke with Joe, who came in for a special appointment on a Sunday morning with us. We were floored the second we walked into the space. An old federal savings bank, this place has the rich history and grandeur you would imagine, but with a charm and beauty that look my breath away. Joe was incredible - walking us through every detail of the way the ceremony would be set up, the HOUR-AND-A-HALF cocktail hour upstairs with 15 passed hors d'oeuvres, 4 stationary tables, and open bar, and then the reception downstairs with a four-course dinner, including dessert course and more open bar. And, their hotel is right across the street - none of our guests would have to drive anywhere. We were sold. Especially when we found out that they were actually cheaper than some of the other places we had been looking at previously. 

Our wedding day was PERFECTION. I work as an event planner, so I am used to managing every detail of event days myself. The folks at the Franklin Plaza took care of absolutely everything. There was never a question in my mind that our wedding would be anything less than exquisite. The head waiters and site managers were incredible, and we had everything we needed taken care of for us all night. I didn't have to lift a finger. The food was incredible. You could really tell that Michael's catering (through the Franklin Plaza) was truly a chef and caterer, not just your run-of-the-mill event venue cranking out the typical steak, chicken, fish. They did every single meal to order, served every one of my 180 guests in record time, and kept everyone happy - and FULL - all night long. 

There is honestly not a bad thing I could possibly say about this venue. I would suggest that anyone looking for a terrific venue for their wedding, bar Mitzi, anniversary party, ANYTHING visit the Franklin Plaza. If you ever get an invitation for an event at the Franklin Plaza, go! Even if you don't even like the person inviting you. Go anyway to check out this incredible place and have an amazing experience like I had. It's that good.

I like this place for the cute retro-vibe of the cooks and staff wearing  whites. It's a little shack type place where you walk up, order, and receive your food shortly afterward. 

After hearing all of this buzz about Jack's, I decided to give it a whirl. 

On the whole, the food was just not there. The burger didn't really have much flavor - it was just a thin patty cooked well with some onions on top. I didn't think it was too greasy, though.
The fries were soggy and I think they could have used longer in the fryer to crisp them up a bit. A bit undercooked, perhaps?
I took a bite or two, but ended up not eating the food for the most part - nothing particularly off putting, but nothing really making me want to go back for more.

Stayed on 3/31/12. The room was clean and neat. Didn't see any trash out back in the parking area, and the breakfast was fine. All in all it's everything you would expect from a mid-level motel. Nothing outstanding, just a decent quiet place to spend the night then grab a little breakfast before heading out the next day. We would stay again.

A very nice old-fashioned diner. Portions are large, if you care. The food is good and very greasy spoony in a comfort food kind of way. A quiet local crowd mornings and a raucous college crowd late at night.

Very very good South Indian food. Not the absolute best I've eaten but pretty close. Lively but polite service. They can be very busy on the weekends so it's best to make a reservation. We had a reservation and were half an hour late, yet they held the table for us and received us with a smile. Only real negative (minor one albeit) was the restroom could have been better. 
Would definitely visit again.

Good local place to have a no frills dinner. Pizza is good. wings are alright. If you order hot, make sure you like em hot. They are usually drenched in sauce. Sauce is good on all the italian dishes. And they have amazing Italian dressing. I was really disappointed in the cheesecake tho. I asked for cherries and they put marachino cherries on. Its a good thing for them I got it to go, because I took one bite and had to throw it out. It just tasted old and freezer burnt. Hopefully next time I'll have a better experience, as I usually love the place.
Wow! So glad I went here. VERY good ice cream, unique flavors, lots of cone options. Very patiently allow you to try samples of flavors. I only wish I could try them all in one sitting!

we miss defazio's!   true,  the atmosphere isn't much, but after discovering defazio's chicken fra diavolo, we were addicted.  for years it was our regular pizza fix.   we had to move away from the area in 2000, and have since lived in other parts of new york and in four other states.  but we still talk about defazio's!  it's the best pizza we've had and we've tried dozens of other places.  just know how lucky you are if you live near by...  some day we'll come back to the area for a visit and defazio's will be our first stop.

My wife and I were discussing all of our friends weddings we had attended in the past couple of years.

Outside of our own (duh), our absolute favorite was held at Franklin Plaza. The inside is comfy and pretty if not a shade dated. The food was somewhere between decent and excellent depending on the item. The staff were super nice and helpful. The inside setup for the ceremony was beautifully done.

Overall I would definitely recommend this as a potential location for anyone looking to get married in the area.

Not your grandpa's deli! 
I love it as a deli, bakery, middle-eastern/Israeli and an Eastern European deli. Great selection of salads, smoked meats and fish, baked goods - check out the unique Hungarian dessert. Sandwiches are huge, I always take half of it home. Much better ambiance than Gershon;s in Schenectady, quieter, lighter, airier. Interesting selection of of dry mixes (rice, pasta_ to take home. Great breads too.

The Purple Pub is an institution and is always very busy when I've been here for dinner and team pizza parties, as a kid. The pizza is very good and the prices are reasonable. However, the place is very crowded and noisy and the parking lot can get full. The last time my group tried to eat here, we had to wait over an hour for a table and we ended up hanging out in the bar instead.

I first read about Karavalli a few years ago when they were reviewed in a local paper.  We had just moved from the San Francisco Bay Area to Albany, NY and was desperate to find "ethnic" cuisines that we were so used to finding in the San Francisco metro area.  I poured over the local dining guides in search of something else than "pizza", meat and potatoes, pasta, and typical Mall fare (well, you get the idea) -- and fortunately, found the review on Karavalli.  

We visited Karavalli in Latham 6 months after they had just opened.  We met with their Chef/Owner since he had plenty of time to talk to people because his restaurant was just "new" and they were still in search of customers.  We have returned many times since and the Chef/Owner would always stop by our table to say "hello".  We appreciated those small gestures and have returned the favor by giving him more business.  

Fast forward several years later, we have returned to the San Francisco Bay Area and I felt a fair review of Karavalli was in the works.  Honestly, I give it 5-stars.  The food is good, well made, no compromising of taste, and practically consistent.  If a dish is supposed to be "spicy" then so be it because that's the way it's supposed to be.  Anything less is like asking McDonald's to go vegetarian or Starbucks to use Folgers.  

We love their buffet lunch.  Not a lot of choices compared to Indian restaurants in Silicon Valley where they have huge vats of stuff and over 20 choices, but what you get at Karavalli is what they do best -- offer you delicious Indian cuisine.  No more, no less.  

If we are in the Albany area again, we will certainly stop by Karavalli to have authentic South Indian cuisine.
So far, the best pierogis and golumpkies  in the area.  Great flavor and well made. They're as good as mine!

Owner/chef Marla had the food quality nailed from the moment she opened her doors -- front of house? Not so much. Through most of her first year of operation, lets just say service was homey and extremely casual.

Don't know what happened, but recently, her waitstaff turned over almost 100%, and the new team is much faster, more efficient, and on the ball. Perhaps still not a match for the amazing standards Marla sets in the kitchen, but a huge improvement nevertheless.

I give the Illium extra points for savvy ingredient purchasing that lets them keep the prices lower than you would expect for such good food.

Don't miss this place - it's a treasure.

My parents drag me here every time I come home for a visit.  They call it "their place." (Cute, but kind of lame).

Their beer deserves 5 stars, with the stouts and pale ales being the best.

The menu sometimes makes me laugh and I still have yet to have a satisfying meal here.  The bar food is obviously good, but order anything else from the rest of the menu and it's pretty hit or miss.  And for some dang reason, I'm always in the mood for fish when I come, and I stupidly order fish thinking "oh, maybe this time it will be good." It never is. The worst menu item of all is the bbq pork chops.  Thin slices of pork with a stingy portion of bbq sauce.  Probably one of the worst meals I've ever had, ever.

The one thing the entrees have going for them is the red cabbage side dish.  

Long story short, this is clearly a pub.  If you just stick with ordering from the appetizers menu or anything else that can be labled as "pub food" (i.e, anything that comes fried or in sandwich form) you won't be disappointed.

Stewart's has the best ice cream by far. However, and I usually don't like cake, but nothing beats Carvel. Nothing.

The way they do the vanilla/chocolate crumbs/chocolate is tried and true, and I used to eat entire cakes by myself when I was little. This store is mostly take out of course, it's blank white with a Shaker or Siena student working the register.

Take your pick: there's cakes of all sizes lined up for your liking, and I remember I got one for my dad's birthday and just put, "You're getting older". What an asshole I was haha.

The chocolate crumb-y middle of the cake is definitely worth it, it's the munch to the soft ice cream surrounding and brings me back so well. And it's cheap too. When you scarf down an entire small cake for like 8 bucks, I say it's worth it.

This particular location is 5 minutes away from me in Loudonville when I'm home for the holidays and such. Newton Plaza really does have it all.

The beer at Brown's is as good as ever, but since they changed chefs a few months ago the food is terrible and overpriced. I've been to Brown's several times since the new chef, and the food is consistently bad. As an example, last night I went with a few others and we got the nachos to share: a middling-sized plate of tri-color chips with cheap nacho cheese sauce, olive slices, a few jalapeno slices, a few chunks of mushy tomato, salsa and sour cream. Those nachos cost $12.49. Absurd.
I love Brown's beer, and that's the only reason they get two stars. For the food, I award them no points, and may God have mercy on their souls.

Welcome to Moe's!

Java ++ is being converted into a Moe's Southwest Grill (open to the public) and should be open by August 2011.

Stopped in for a sundae. The prices are very reasonable and the portions are alot more manageable then other ice cream stands where you end up throwing away half of it. The soft serve is creamy and they have hot caramel. (Although I didn't care for it.) Tasted burnt to me. 

CASH ONLY

DeFazio's is hands-down the best pizza in the capital region. I have yet to find a place with the quality, atmosphere, and friendly attitude. It's a true Italian establishment where you really are "treated like family".

Every pizza, regardless of the preparation and topping choices, is created with quality and technique that is unmatched at any other Italian eatery you'll find nearby. The vegetables are fresh, the meats are tasty, and the sauce is perfection. Any pie is more expensive than it would be at an average pizza joint, but if quality and taste is what you seek, fork over the extra $7 and pick up any of their delicious options. 

I have seen two reviews dissing the crust. Apparently, some people don't find it crispy enough. I have never felt like the crust wasn't to my liking and/or a single slice felt soggy, but maybe that's just my opinion. 

Besides pizza, their other options are also amazing. Calzones are equally delicious (and are huge, by the way). Salads are fantastic. I recommend any of their appetizers, especially if you're dining in for pizza as the main course. Each of their pies is treated like a work of art, and therefore take a little while to come out. Sidenote: if you're ordering pizza from here for delivery, be prepared for it to take a while, for the same reason. 

Staff is super friendly and accommodating, but the restaurant is not huge. I usually get takeout or delivery, but if it's not a busy night, dining in is also an excellent option. Reservations are welcomed. Overall, a great place, and fantastic pizza in Troy's Little Italy neighborhood.
Really decent pizza, large pie's with great price.  Delivery always seems to be from 45min to a hour, so we usually pick-up from the location.  But it's the best pizza we've had in the neighborhood.

Polish food right by RPI, it's perfect when the weather starts to get cold.  

The pierogis and stuffed cabbage are great, I wasn't too keen on the potato pancakes, a little soggy in my experience.  

Reasonable prices as well, a must go in the winter.  And the owners are so nice, it feels like home, and not just because it clearly once was one.

Ok so I'm a grocery store junkie. I like going to a nice clean grocery store that has high quality prepared foods and a good variety of everything else.

Hannaford's is clean and well organized. The quality of their food is better than average. I don't know -- it's hard for me to explain it, but I just like being at Hannaford's. 

I don't know if all Hannafords have a Redbox but this one does.

Unfortunately, the Albany area doesn't have a Whole Foods Market or Trader Joe's, but I think if I had to live here, I'd be okay because there's Hannaford's.
Wonderful atmosphere.big portions with no lack of taste. The croutons in the salad and creamy italian dressing of the best in the area

Really above-average selection of antiques/beautiful old furniture.  Almost every piece is a keeper.  Don't miss the separate small room next to the main space (it also has a window on the street). If I bought a house, I would love to just order up the contents of this room to furnish it!  Beautiful tables, bowls, mirrors, dressers, chests...

Pizza in Troy is a glorious thing.  Coming from the vapid void that is Albany, I was stoked to find out Troy has so many good pizza joints.  DeFazio's, Red Front, & I Love are the 3 biggest favs if you ask a Trojan.  Well, Dante's needs to be added to the vocabulary of everyone in the area.  Their crust reminds me of foccacia, its light & airy with a hint of its own seasoning.  Their sauce is the killer ingredient though.  Its got a kick, a little heat, almost like a fra diavolo.  The cheese isn't heaped on, which when you first see the pie and notice how much crust and sauce you can see is a little off putting, but believe me the combination of ingredients is amazing and makes me keep coming back at least once every week or so.  Don't even hesitate and give em a shot!

So, where's the dairy, Duncan?

I came here with the first group of brave Lame Ass Monthly Breakfast tour attendees. I'd say our group was pretty much in accord in terms of our overall impression of Duncan's, so consider their reviews an addendum to mine.

Duncan's is squeezed uncomfortably between being a diner and a greasy spoon. If they didn't have a good amount of staff, the lack of attention would have been understandable. But with so many people running around at any given time, I was surprised that my coffee cup was empty for as long as it was. But damn, they do have some good coffee. 

I initially thought Duncan's would be a great location to have a meetup with more than 4 people, but I was sadly mistaken. There appears to be one table that can comfortably seat more than 4 tucked away in a back corner. We ended up splitting into a group of 4 and 2 taking two tables next to each other. The general noise level made it hard for us to communicate, but we made due. 

I ordered the Spanish omelet, which was just ok. Nothing special.

The true test of a diner/greasy spoon, for me, is the hash browns. On that front, Duncan's gets a solid thumbs down. Seems as though they tossed the potatoes in a generous amount of lard but didn't give them enough time to get crispy, so they were just greasy, tasteless, and unpleasant. 

The coffee is good enough to push them up to a 3. Maybe we'll have better luck coming back on a not so busy day with less people.

I stayed here on a Wed. night and enjoyed my visit.   $67 on Hotwire--a fair value at $90 per night, but I wouldn't spend much more than that, particularly given that it's a good 20 minute drive from downtown Albany. The room was spacious, clean, and comfortable, and I also liked the fact that there was a pool and a free breakfast with lots of choices.  

Suggestion--update the fitness center equipment.  I realize that a fitness center isn't necessary--but if you're going to have one, why not have it come with treadmills that aren't ancient and actual weights, not a tacky all-in-one gym?  Also--transport to Albany proper should be a bit cheaper--the $19 + tip shuttle is pretty expensive.  (I came here w/o a car).

Probably the classiest restaurant in Troy, however I like the food at River Street Cafe more.   Whenever my grandparents come to visit we always go here, and the food is very good.  Their halibut entree is really great and I love the lobster risotto that accompanies it.  I also really enjoy their calamari for an appetizer.

The place has a good atmosphere and it is really well decorated.  I would agree with the last poster that there is a little bit of attitude.  One thing I particularly hate is when they ask you what kind of water you want.  "Sparkling, bottled, or wonderful Troy City water".  That is more or less what they ask, and it makes me feel like a bum when I say "City water"  because I don't feel like paying for a bottle of flat water.

They often have someone playing the piano, which is really nice and great background music.  But once or twice they had a band (piano, trumpet, something else) and they were playing ridiculously loud.  We could not even have a conversation at normal volume.

They also have a Sunday brunch buffet, and it is really well done.  One of the better buffets I have ever been to.  Omellette and carving station, pastas, various meats dishes, etc.  Really great and the price is pretty reasonable (20 bucks??? I'm not quite sure).

So the food is great, but the slight attitude and annoyingly loud music keep it from getting 5 stars.

The Fresh Market in Latham is now open! ! My folks and I went to check out the Grand Opening. The place was mobbed due to the newness and being the first store in NYS. I've also shopped at The Fresh Market at Hingham Shipyard, south of Boston, which is a very nice store. 

The parking lot was full, so we had to park across the street. This market looks very nice. It's organized, bright and clean, not as big (sizewise) as the standard suburban supermarket chain (Hannaford & Price Chopper), but similar size as a typical Trader Joe's (which has good prices) and similar concept to the slightly larger Whole Foods Market. 

There are several departments/sections including good selection of fresh produce, freshly prepared foods (sandwiches, entrees, sushi), gourmet salads, meats, deli, cheeses, dairy, seafood, bakery, coffee, snacks, nuts, organic & healthy groceries, flowers, frozen foods, and more. The products sold here tend to be on the pricey side. However, the bakery rocks! I picked up some Almond Croissants and Chocolate Croissants for only $1.29 each and muffins for only 60 cents (regular price $1.09), a great bargain compared to Au Bon Pain where I normally get my sweet treats at double the price. I tried out some free food samples throughout the store including some cheese and BBQ spare ribs cooked on the grill outside, which were dry rubbed, chewy, and salty tasting. 

We will definitely be back to The Fresh Market in Latham since this is a fresh healthy alternative to the other markets in the area, which sell everything else including the inexpensive processed foods. I can also grab a tasty lunch too!
Amazing Indian, and Thai food!  It's as authentic as it gets!

If you're having an off-hours pet emergency, see their website above for hours.  They are only open something like 5pm to 8am on weekdays, and 24 hours on weekends.

I don't have a lot to go on -- I only visited them once. It was in the middle of the night, and they were able to help my cat.  I left a happy customer.

Hmm... I'm getting an eerie feeling that I researched this place on Yelp before I took my cat there.  Now there's no reviews, at all, for it?  That seems odd.

Love this place - great beer and a good vibe, pretty much the best of its kind in the area. Even the food is well done, and not too pricey...its the rare brewpub that has decent vegetarian options, and this place certainly does!
Best fish fries in the Albany area.

I had my 10K service at Cooley and they'd forgotten to reset the "Service Now!" alert so I had to go back. Oops!

It was a bit of a drive for me and I figured I'd kill two birds with one stone. I decided I would have the "Volk-L" Bluetooth phone system installed in my car, even though I hate talking to people on the phone.

I made an appointment and reserved a loaner car with them.

With German promptness I arrived at the dealership first thing in the morning. They informed that they did not have a loaner car for me. Oops!

They arranged a rental car which I had to wait for, and then sent me on my way. Later in the day they called to inform me that they'd forgotten to reserve the Volk-L part for me and accidentally installed it in someone else's car. There was now no Bluetooth phone system to install in my car. Oops!

They said they'd ordered a new part, but would have to keep my car an additional day.

The next day I called to check in. They transferred me to someone. She transferred me to someone. He transferred me to someone. He transferred me to someone else. I kept asking the same question: "Just wanted to know when I can come and pick up my car." Person #4 put me on hold.

Eventually Person #4 returned to the phone and told me to come on down! It'd be ready when I got there. I came on down.

It wasn't ready - because the part was broken and they couldn't get it to work. Oops!

I should add that despite the baffling incompetence they were very, very cheerful. Had they offered me some kind of apology in the form of a discount, I might have given them another chance. But they didn't, so I took advantage of their free WiFi to look for another dealership.

Your mileage may vary, but don't be surprised if it doesn't.

This place headlines and really brings a lot of people down to the waterfront in this section of Troy.  And Troy has some good things going for it, which is great to see.  The beer here is worth staying for, but the food is debatable.

I've eaten here twice, and both times, the beer was great.  I usually stick to the brown ale.  I love drinking brews from the brewery.  But the food really lackluster.  One time, there for dinner, I had a burger with fries.  Nothing too great.  The second time, I was there for brunch and ordered a Monte Cristo.  Both meals suffered from the "Sysco effect".  The food was just bland and felt like it could have come from a Sysco truck.

I've talked with other people who have experienced the same issues I have.  A great place for beer, but get your meal somewhere else.

I'm now here about once a week.  The Fresh Market has made it into a regular rotation, even though it's out of the way.

It's not Whole Foods. It's certainly not Trader Joe's. It's not Wegman's.  

I think it's best to approach this store on its own terms.  A lot of items are pricier than similar items one might find elsewhere.  Sometimes this is because they are overpriced.  But other times it is because The Fresh Market products are actually better.  

- Roast chickens that weren't fed antibiotics (when they were alive).
- Prepackaged sliced cheese made without the use of rBST.
- Grade B maple syrup (which is surprisingly hard to find here).

They have tasty challah at the bakery (although they do come frozen for kosher reasons). The bakery even torches creme brulee to order.  Get the pre-stuffed cannoli at your peril.

Not everything is great, and the service especially at the bakery counter and the deli counter can be slow.  The cheese selection is a major personal disappointment.  But this is by far the nicest place to get groceries in the Capital Region.  

And if you have kids, they can get a card for the cookie club. Every time we are there, the children get a free cookie from the bakery.  When it's time to get more milk, can you guess where the little one's want to go?

I've been here a couple of times visiting a friend at RPI. Good drip coffee, vintage decor is charming and reminiscent of the space's previous existence as jewelry store. The staff is friendly and the food tasty. Definitely worth checking out.
