I attended one of those dreaded work related holiday parties here yesterday.  I was definitely unimpressed. The hors d'oeuvres table was pretty lame, I'm sure the office planners approved the food so I can't fault the facility for the chocolate fountain before lunch but the veggies looked old and tired, the dip was actually just salad dressing, the cheese and crackers were sub par.  Lunch was okay but the service was very disorganized. All the tables around us got their salads while we sat and waited but then we got our entrees before them and were done by the time the table next to us got their food. I had chicken with bland sauce, mashed potatoes and a few green beans. The dessert was either some type of gummy mousse or tiramisu, not really sure.

I had the most amazing wrap here the other day. It was the steak and egg wrap. Soooo delicious...just thinking about it makes my mouth water. Grilled steak, peppers, and onion mixed with scrambled eggs and melted cheese all bundled together in a soft wrap. Yum! I wish I lived closer so I could get one tomorrow morning!

Oh and the coffee drinks are not bad either. I highly recommend the iced mocha carmel latte.

I remember this place when I was little.  I loved it when my Grandfather would take us there.  It was a special place, and I have fond memories of my "Grampa" and the times we spent there :)  Thinking of Hoffmans makes me miss Grampa and wish he were still around.

Me and my boyfriend wanted to treat ourselves out for dinner, and wanted to go to a diner for options. The menu was limited and it's mainly a breakfast place. The service was very slow and there was all of 4 tables there. I got a chicken sandwich, and no joke, it was the size of a white castle burger. The ice tea tasted HORRIBLE. Needless to say we will never be going there again.
The beers are ok, but its too expensive to eat here.  The quality doesn't justify the price.
The cajun chicken ceasar salad is amazing!

Great Ice cream as others have noted. While it is just a little bit pricey for ice cream, its definitely worth the price. Very fast too. If you're ordering soft serve it almost feels like someone in the back is making it before you even pay.

The portions are very large, a "kids" size is about the size of a soda can, and for the sundaes you can get several different toppings. 

I don't order from the grill often but the food is pretty good there as well.

A tip, if you'ore interested in trying something special like the hot fudge brownie with ice cream, try ordering a sundae instead and asking for what you want as a topping. You can get ice cream with brownie and chocolate syrup (practically the same thing) for half the price. 

Make sure to get a punch card when you go! You can turn it in for a free medium after 10 items (not transactions).
Very good indian food.  I've eaten this type of food in different parts of the world and this rates with the best of them.  ...Upscale with tasty food and good service.

One of the few restaurants in the North Greenbush area that is truly delicious and fresh. I've been to Garlic Lovers several times now ever since it opened. If some of you stopped by in the beginning months, it used to be more of a pronounced take out place. Now it is quite fancy if you ask me. I had the pan fried Mahi Mahi, cooked to perfection and served with couscous and fresh veggies. I would also recommend the Pan seared scallops...mmm. Their Moroccan chicken stew over orzo is also a pleasant surprise with a jolt of spice. The falafel sandwich is pretty standard but I think that you should try something nicer since it is available.

This place really raises the bar for Indian restaurants in the area.  The food is high quality, served up by a skilled waitstaff, in a dining room that is clean and elegant.  The spicy dishes such as Vindaloo and Phal are legitimately hot while remaining flavorful.  Some of the other menu items including the Calcutta Jewish specials are unique creations I haven't seen before.  Karavalli also has a liquor license, so you can enjoy a beer or a cocktail with your meal.  The prices are on the higher side, but not unreasonable.  A good addition to the local restaurant scene!

As surprising as it may seem - the pizza here is actually pretty good. 

I picked one up on the way home yesterday. The crust has good texture (crispy yet maintaining a certain chewiness). The sauce had nice flavor (just wish there was a little more on the pizza). The toppings were just what you would expect from peperoni and cheese. 

The large was a little small (maybe 14 inches???) but hey -size doesn't matter, right? 

Overall a good pizza that hit the spot.

Ted's Fish Fry now has an official website and a Facebook page! Congrats on almost 60 years in business!

They have some very cool photos on both, hehe :-O

WEBSITE: http://www.tedsfishfry.net

FACEBOOK: http://www.facebook.com/pages/Watervliet-NY/Teds-Fish-Fry/240983270362

I'm new to the area and asked around at work for a local nail salon.  I was in need of a pedicure and a little relaxation, so off I went to City Nail after two people recommended it.  The salon was clean and they were able to get me in right away without an appointment...definitely a plus.  The chairs are comfortable and the pedicure was fine.  That's it...just fine.  I guess I was just spoiled by the attention to detail at my favority spa back home, but I'd prefer more time spent on trimming/cleaning and less on the massage.  Overall, the experience was okay but I'll be looking for another salon next time.

One word can be used to describe, AWESOME!  From the owner to the cooks, to cleanliness, oh and not to mention the delicious and fresh food!  Beats out any BBQ joint around, Dino doesn't even come close!  Try it's awesomeness and see for yourself!

I stumbled upon this place during Troy's "antidote to Black Friday" shopping night. It's a ceramic studio with a beautiful selection up for sale: it's a great place to find a small gift or a large collector's piece.

Interesting shop to browse but save your money before signing up for a lesson.  The owner ran a special on groupon and said she was too overwhelmed by the response to return calls to schedule a time. Unfortunately I got the lesson as a present, not a groupon cheapie. The instruction was minimal,  owner was distracted, we got barely an hour and a "special" day was anything but.  Save your money, even if you get a "deal". Not worth the trip to  dead  "downtown" Troy.

Paesan's was one of the places in my area where I ordered pizza from. The previous reviewer is dead on about the pizza, too much cheese, not enough sauce, and not enough toppings on the whole pies. I say just order the slices which seem to have more toppings and taste decent, especially after going to the bars. I've had better pizza.

"Brewing Brown Ale is to Believe"
by Josh K.

Heaven can best described as sitting out on a deck on the Hudson River with a pint of Brown Ale in hand.

You may be mad that I equate a Troy brewery with our eternal resting spot in the clouds.

At first glance, you would be justified.

Browns Brewing Company does not have great food...it is very average.

When it is crowded, the service is horrible.

When there is a live band, it is too loud...and crowded.

But take a sip of any of their beers brewed on premises, and you are an instant believer.

The Smoked Whiskey Barrel Porter, the Oatmeal Stout, the fresh and fruity Cherry Raspberry Ale, or their signature Brown Ale, all are extremely delicious.

If you need a little relief from the crowd, the deck out back overlooking the Hudson River is a great place to hangout.

The cheap sliders on NFL Sunday are also a nice snack to go along with the homemade beer.

But what it really comes down to is the simple fact that because I love their beer, I can't help but to love this place.

With Jose Malone's, River Street Cafe, Revolution Hall, Ryan's Wake, and Dinosaur Barbeque all on the same little strip on the Hudson, the River Street neighborhood of Troy is easily my favorite section of the Capital Region.

And the Brown Ale is Holier than thou.
pretty good food, nice decoration and cheaper than expectation

After hearing about The Judge's Inn for some time now, I decided to try it for lunch.

First off, the restaurant is beautiful, there is a nice little stage for live music, a game room with a pool table and darts, not to mention to beautiful ceiling- just look at it to glimpse Troy's golden days.  

This place takes the legal theme and runs with it.  When handing you your subpoena-like menu, the waiter says "you have been served."  Furthermore, all of the items are either named for legal cases, laws, or famous judges or lawyers.  

For the food, the menu is extensive and there are many unique choices.  Not every pub fries their potato chips to order, makes their own pastrami, or uses chipotle aioli.  I tried the Em O, the fried pickles, and they were delicious- served with a very hot, but cool, chipotle aioli.  I ordered the Oliver Wendell Holmes, a sandwich of 2 crab cakes, garlic aioli, canadian bacon, and the fixings- it was delicious, though my one complaint was the cakes were a tad salty- nothing too bad, though.  My brother got a monster of a burger- cheese, canadian bacon, all on rye bread- it too was very good but a little too brown to truly be medium, still it was very juicy.  My dad ordered the pastrami sandwich with red cabbage slaw- it was delicious.  Although, it got even better with a side of grainy brown mustard, something I think they should include on the plate without having to ask for.  

Overall this was delicious pub food at a reasonable price.  The atmosphere was great and I just dig this place's style.  I know it's picky but I would like a little better presentation for the dishes- there's nothing wrong with the simple presentation I received, but if the presentation matched the taste, this place would be perfect.
Another nice hidden gem of Troy. Good food and a nice beer selection. It's small but fun.
If whole foods got together with trader joes and had a baby bam they'd name it Fresh market.  Love the sashimi grade tuna for 11 bucks a lb . Didn't see any two Buck chuck though

On the Farm has great soft serve ice cream.  The kind of soft serve that leaves me wondering "why doesn't all soft serve taste this good?"

I wouldn't necessarily eat lunch here, or order any of the fried things, but every time I am in town I try to go by On the Farm, remember 1986 (when they opened) and smile at the fact that the soft serve tastes as good as it did then.
This is my preferred grocery store in the capital region. Their prices are much cheaper than Price Chopper. The store is very clean and well organized and the produce is always fresh and tasty.

I had to get my bridesmaids dress altered within a week time frame and this place did a fantastic job! I would recommend this place to anyone that needs a good job done for a great price. Location is also convenient and service extremely nice.
Not very good at all would not recommend very thick crust

I've eaten here probably 30 times in the last 3 years. The food is always excellent, but the service has gone downhill lately. I will continue to come here because I really like the beer and the fact that we can fill up our growlers. If you want to eat within a reasonable amount of time, do NOT come here during dinner time on a weekend.

I hve been doing business with Langan Audi East for some time. I have always had a good experience in all of my dealings. Staff is always very friendly and willing to help. I am on my third vehicle from Langan and will returning soon to look for a car for my daughter. Great brand and great dealership!

I've read some pretty bad reviews on this place on other sites, but I wanted to put in my two cents. I've been living here for over 2 years now and I've really enjoyed it. The rent is expensive but for the amenities I think it's a great value. I love my beautiful apartment and don't plan on leaving any time soon. I never hear noise from any neighbors and no one ever bothers us. A couple of things have broken over the years but nothing a work order can't fix. You can definitely tell the stuff is cheap...my fridge had a plastic part that cracked, my lazy susan cracked, and the insulating strip under the front door is always just coming off. We've had it replaced once and we need another one again. That is pretty annoying, bugs start getting in!! Other than that...I love my vaulted ceilings, my huge guest bathroom, my nice big pantry, and the washer/dryer IN OUR UNIT!! I can't tell you what a convenience that is! In the summer time it is so nice to use the pool (but I don't like to go at a time when kids are all home because it gets really overrun by little kids. I also wish you could bring some beers in but you can't drink alcohol in the pool area. oh well.) I also wish there was a younger crowd living here, we don't really know any of our neighbors because they're mostly families or old retired couples. 

The WORST thing about this place is the parking situation. It's a nightmare. I've had to park as far as 2 buildings away from where I actually live, its so terrible. They did not plan this place very well when they built it. I dread looking for a parking space!!
Good food - cheap price - quick delivery. What more could you as for.

They have the best Salmon BLT i've ever had in my life.
I had their red velvet cake..it was ok, but the sandwich is mind blasting!
MUST HAVE!

I've been to this yoga studio on several occasions now. The experience has been a bit different each time, but overall very positive. The studio is heated to the mid 90's and keeps your body warm and limber.

I took a class with Susan and she proved herself to be one of the best yoga instructors I've ever had. The class was full of experienced students. I' not a total newbie but I'm not really that good either.  
She guided the class through a complex routine. Some of it I had never seen before, and she got us to do things that I didn't dream were possible.

I've taken a class with Emily the owner who pretty much just blew me out of the water. She has a devoted cohort and the class was packed. To say is was challenging is an understatement, and the students loved her for it. These are the people who thrive on a punishing workout.  

They would have a 5 star review if it were not for the cramped check in area, and no locker room or changing room other than the bathroom. The studio is very popular and the Monday evening I was there hosted so many people that it was hard to move around in the check in area.
The pizza from here is pretty good (for a chain), their customer service on the other hand... IS HORRIBLE!

I'm a fan of Fresh Market, but there a few things that bother me.  I think they could have more organic products and carry more local products.  I think they try to give out the organic vibe, but they fall short.  It is extremely clean and nicely laid out which is nice.  It gives out an upscale vibe both from the outside and when you walk in. 

I really like their meats.  My personal favorite is the chimichuri hanger steaks.  Mmmm.  I could easily eat them once a week.  They also have good prepared foods.  I really like their rotisserie chicken salad and actually their rotisserie chickens.  They also have delicious curry chicken salad.  I was a little disappointed to see the same old crappy ingredients in some of their baked sweet goodies, but I think that's almost to be expected in those type of things.  

I think if you stick to the prepared foods and meats you won't be disappointed.  Mostly everything I have gotten has been great.

The people who work here are definitely friendlier than the employees at your run of the mill supermarket as well.

Overall Fresh Market does a good job.  I do feel the prices are a little high, but the alternatives in this area are pretty awful except for the co-op.

I have not bought a car here. So I can speak on that. This dealership is maybe 8 minutes from my house, so I bring my Jetta here for service. Greg and Kelsey are by far the best service people I have dealt with at any dealership. They always find away to squeeze me in, even if its for a simple oil change. Or took 10% off my bill when I didn't have a coupon. They try to go out of their way when and where they can, so be nice to them, and don't be afraid to ask for a discount.

This place is perfect for a family with young children on a budget. No admission fees is the key here. Most rides cost 1 ticket and they have a 8 tickets for $11.50 deal. The rides are nothing spectacular but they are perfect for young children. My 2 year old loved this place. They also take credit cards which is a plus. Staff is very friendly and parking is convenient.

When your wife calls and says "I've had a terrible day at work, would you like to go out for a beer," you do like I did... turn off whatever you were cooking on the stove, and tell her you'll leave in five minutes to meet her.

And so we met at Brown's.  The "beer of the day" was an American Wheat Ale ($3.75 /16 oz all day) - 5% abv, crisp, slightly fruity, unfiltered.  The Pumpkin Ale ($5.25 /16 oz every day) - 7% abv, nice mahogany-bronze color, a hint of orange, and in my opinion, NOT sweet and spicy like a pumpkin pie, but slightly sweet, dry and clean tasting.  Those beers kept us satisfied while we ordered and discussed a day at work.

My wife chose one of the day's specials, the Mushroom, Beef and Swiss Quesadilla ($11.99) - chopped steak, caramelized onions, mushrooms and imported Swiss in a flour tortilla, served with Brown's chipotle ketchup, sour cream and salsa.  Other than a couple pieces of grizzle, this was very good, especially the chipotle ketchup.

I ordered a Hickory Chicken Sandwich ($10.49) - southern fried with cheddar, bacon, cherry raspberry ale BBQ sauce, crispy onions, lettuce, and tomato on a ciabatta roll.  Very tasty, but difficult to eat since the roll was very thick and the BBQ sauce made the chicken slide out of the sandwich.  The accompanying fries were reallllly good dipped in my wife's chipotle ketchup.

An Oatmeal Stout ($4.75 /16 oz) - 5.5% abv, was its usual flavorful, award-winning self.  Their Oktoberfest ($4.75 /16 oz) - 5.5% abv, was nice, with a slight sweetness, but not as flavorful as one I had recently at Druther's in Saratoga.

Service was good, but the upstairs dining area was drafty and cold until they closed an adjacent door and more people sat in the area.  Bottom like, Brown's makes some excellent beers.  Without the beer, I'd probably only go 3 stars, however.

The potato pancakes were good, and extremely fried. I mean, they were thin, crunchy, and dripping with grease. It was great. I got two things of apple sauce, because the waitress thought I would want some--I didn't ask, she just decided to be extra nice. The staff is extremely friendly; it's all an in-house family operation. Even their website was designed by the owner's son.

I had the Banana crunch, described on their website as:
Two Fried Bananas topped with a crunchy Peanut butter, Vanilla cream, & brandy sauce.
but described more accurately as an orgasm for your mouth. Eat it. Eat it.

Not just a place for delicious wood fired neapolitan pizza, but a place for awesome craft brew and a short but decent wine list AND yummy desserts.  

Something they don't  emphasize enough is how much is made in house: dough, mozzarella, sauces, and desserts and often from local sources. 

In addition to pizza and pasta you can get a salad with any of the toppings generously piled on fresh greens.  

I also had a conversation with the owner one time about some of the earth friendly circumstances of the building itself and the operation.  (I was under the influence of several glasses of wine so I'm a little foggy on details)

The crust has improved over the years and is still light and crisp and is at its best when the humidity is down.  Sadly, I do not think the pizza, the crust being a delicate as it is, travels well, so it is best to eat it in house.  

Despite Daisy Bakers claiming to be the unofficial after party spot for Troy Night Out, it really is Bacchus Wood-Fired that everyone is hanging out at.

We ordered three different lamb curry under the special column and one salmon curry for lunch, though it takes longer time to prepare the food than going directly for the lunch buffet. The food is tasty and We like the naan and roti a lot~
The one thing that I dont like is that the mango lessi and shake are soooooo sweat that I just cant finish it...

I am in love with this place!

First, they have the coolest pizza oven ever.  That alone deserves 5 stars. 
The atmosphere is funky basement brick.
The music they play is great.  

Next...the food. Oh, the food!  I love it!
The pizza's are thin, crisp, light and very fresh with endless topping 
Same for the pasta.  Huge portions with endless pasta/sauce/ toppings combos.
We didn't get pasta but saw what was being served next to us and we will be back to try some of that!

The libations include a revolving selection of microbrews and wine by the glass.  We ordered  a glass of Carmenere and a pint of Goose Island Harvest.  Both were excellent.  Our serve told us that the draft selection constantly changes to reflect the seasons.

There was trivia happening in the bar tonight (Tuesday)' so we chose to sit in one of the booths instead of the bar area.  The space is divided into several dining areas.  Bar, Booth area, dining room by the cool pizza oven or outside if you can manage to snag one of those tables.  they also have a funky little hidden room!

We ate a lot but weren't put into food coma status because of the light freshness of the food.  We ordered the garlic cheese bread to start which was unique and so good. I think it was made with their pizza dough and It came with a side of mixed stuff such as lettuce, spicy peppers and feta cheese.  And it was plentiful when it came to cheese and garlic.  

Then came the pizza.  We ordered two.  WOW!  We asked our server what pizzas are the most popular and we ordered the Mozzabella consisting of home made meatballs, home made fresh mozzarella , baby spinach and fresh garlic and basil.  This was really good.  The next pizza was one with fresh pesto , mixed cheeses and very fresh large shrimp.  We loved both.

As stuffed as we were we ordered a dessert to split.  We saw our server bring something to the table next to us that looked so good.  She told us it was a lemon raspberry cake.  We asked about the other desserts and chose a chocolate, peanut butter and brownie cake that was also to die for!

The food was beyond amazing.
Our server was great.
Our bill was something like $45 for 2 drinks, an appetizer, 2 pizzas and dessert.
YES YES YES!

Why oh why did you change your menu soooo drastically? No more mozzarella stuffed bread or pasta w/ clams. Also, appears the batter for the o-rings and calamari has changed or it just wasn't cooked right b/c it was certainly sub-par to what I've had before there. Not to mention I don't think that the calamari was even finished cooking as it was just chewy and rubbery.

The roasted mediterranean sandwich was ok...nothing to blow me over. Good thing for the garlic mayo to make up the flavor. For fresh veggies, no one particular flavor particularly popped in my mouth. Only good thing is that now you can get fries w/ your meal w/o that upcharge. 

My sister said her juicy lucy the burger itself ok, but the cheese not so good. The traditional juicy lucy is made w/ american cheese from my understanding and our experience....if you're going to change it, not something that tastes like blue cheese please.

Beer pretzels though w/ a glass of summer ale....muah, perfecto as usual!

Please please review the new menu and please make some changes!

The crust is too thick, it was undercooked, and the sauce was bland.  The worst part, however, was the customer service.  I called to order and was told that it would be ready in 25 minutes.  When I walked in the door 25 minutes later, I was told 3 or 4 more minutes.  10 minutes later, when I was finally presented with my pizzas, I mentioned that it had taken longer than I was told - twice - at which point the man behind the counter argued with me that it only takes 3 or 4 minutes to cook a pizza (really?), so it couldn't possibly have been 10 minutes.  Apparently their clock just runs really fast.

Decent Chinese takeout. When I'm visiting my buddy who lives around the corner, we sometimes order Chinese takeout or delivery ($11 min) from the Golden House located in the Hill Top strip plaza. They offer 39 Luncheon Specials ($4.65-$5.25 plus tax) served with pork fried rice & choice of soup, egg roll, or soda and 26 All Day Combination Platters ($6.25-$7.25 plus tax) served with pork fried rice & egg roll. 

We usually get the Shrimp Lo Mein (mushy noodle texture) and General Tso's Chicken combo deals. The food is on the salty side (MSG) and very filling. The service here is fairly quick (open kitchen) and the prices are pretty good.

NOTE: No credit cards accepted.

After a friend sent me an online review on The Flying Chicken, my husband and I decided to try it out. Boy, I'm glad that we did! We each got the chicken and waffles (a combination that neither of us had ever tried). We also got an order of hush puppies, mac 'n cheese and a biscuit. 

Where to begin? We live nearby, so got the food to go. The biscuit came out as soon as we got in the car. It was different than most biscuits that I've had before, but in a good way. There was a strong black pepper flavor (not too strong - just right) and definitely buttery. While it was soft and moist on the inside, it was nice and crispy on the outside. Yum!!

The hush puppies (my husband's choice) were quite good and very flavorful. Also somewhat heavy (as hush puppies are wont to be), but worth it! The chicken was boneless and freaking AMAZING! It was not greasy at all, but the flavor (again quite peppery) was great. It was everything I look for in fried chicken and then some. The waffles were sweet, light and surprisingly tasty with the chicken. I got three of the food groups - sweet, savory and crunchy. 

The only thing that was less than spectacular was the mac 'n cheese. Don't get me wrong - it was good, but not flavorful enough to rate as high as all the other things we tried. 

The restaurant itself is clean, well-lit and has some great chicken themed art on the walls. I HIGHLY recommend checking out this new Troy dining experience. I look forward to going back and trying some other of the yummies on the menu.

The pizza sucks, and it is a scam against RPI students. A slice of gourmet now costs $3, while for $5 at I Love's you can get 2 slices and a drink. They also won't take any credit cards on anything less than a $5 order, which I've heard is illegal. Don't go here.

If you enjoy authentic golumpkies, perogies, and kielbasa, you have to try Muza's "Polish Feast"!  I've tried other places that serve Polish in the area, and only Muza has a chef that can make something comparable to Mom's recipe. Nice job!

I keep wanting to come back here & I'm not 100% sure why. The wings are great, but the menu is pretty average. The clam chowder (which I'm big on recently) is Manhattan style. Maybe its the old school never been updated since the day it opened decor. Maybe its just that I love dark dank hole in the walls. Whatever, I love this place.

This is the best woodfire pizza around the capital district (and my favorite place to eat in Troy).  I love the character and casual atmosphere.  Excellent beer and wine selection too.  I usually order the margherita or mozze bella pizza, salad, and roasted garlic bulb.  Makes for a great meal to share.

The beer is good, but to my surprise, the only one that blew me away was the pilsner.  The food is pretty decent.  I had the wings which were lightly breaded and unevenly doused in hot sauce.  They were big and meaty and well-cooked, but I usually like them swimming in buffalo sauce.  It was accompanied by a really delicious bleu cheese dressing with big chunks of bleu cheese in what tasted more like sour cream than a creamy dressing base.  Also had the pulled pork sandwich which was OK, except for that it was covered in cheddar cheese and the BBQ sauce was only added as a condiment, like ketchup on a burger.  Great atmosphere, but the service and clientele leaves something to be desired, but maybe that's just me coming from the midwest...

Somewhat pricier than the competition in the area but the quality and quantity are both there. The Chicken Vindaloo is especially spicy and will make you sweat. The service is friendly and attentive and the decor is a lot classier than other Indian restaurants in the area. The food is well prepared with premium ingredients and the portions are more than enough.

Went in with a small group for dinner 9ish on a Saturday night - was immediately able to be seated at a high-top in the bar area. The waitress / bartender was friendly, attentive, and knowledgeable on the extensive tap selection. The wood-fired pizzas were great - crust cooked to perfection. Be sure to get the shrimp artichoke dip appetizer. And definitely save room for dessert!

Great little sliders with lots of grease. I can smell the onions into Troy. My wife and I stop here during the summer and get a whole plate of greasy sliders, greasy fries, and some soft drinks and have a feast out on one of the picnic tables. All that grease goes down hard.

Where are my Rolaids????

4 and half is my actual rating.

The beer selection is rather pitiful compared to other bars in walking distance (ex: holmes and watsons, the ruck and of course browns) BUT that just means I usually get liquor here. 
The prices are good.  $8 for a double Jameson and ginger.  The drinks are also STRONG. If you get one, don't drive home anytime soon. I'm not a great liquor holder to begin with but I have been with stonger drinkers than I and they agree.

The bartenders aren't overly friendly but I haven't had any bad experiences.

The decor is quite charming as stated before. The bathrooms are quite adorable.   They also have some fun options to play.  SKEEBALL? come on!  AWESOME.  Along with darts, foos ball and pac man and some other games.   Most of them are in separate areas which bodes well with my anti-social tendencies. 

They also have a small back area that's wonderful in the warmer months for a cigarette and lovely conversation. 

I do agree with the other reviewers that I'd rather you not come here and spoil the fun but I'd really rather this place stick around. =]

Went here on Saturday night with great expectations for a four star yelp review.  I was actually pretty disappointed...

First, the bring your own bottle of wine no longer applies (I of course brought my own wine and it just sat on our table), now they sell their own wine $6-10 per glass.

Appetizers:  We had the grape leaves which were just ok.  A little on the bland side and nothing that I would care to have again.

Main course: I had the lamb stew (which I would give 4 stars) it was very tender and delicious.  My husband had the lamb kebab. The waitress warned that this would be served medium, to which he replied "perfect!".  They actually came out pretty well done and were fairly tough and not very flavorful.  I feel like there's more flavor on "fake meat" from any street cart in Manahattan.  

Dessert: We got the baklava to go.  It was made with peanuts!  I'm no expert on greek/mediterranean food, but all the baklava I've ever had in the past contained some combination of gooey chopped walnuts or almonds or pistachio smothered with honey.  This one contained dry chopped peanuts and barely any honey or syrup or whatever the sugary goodness that is usually inside baklava!  Again, greatly disappointing.

Atmosphere: Very cute restaurant, nice ambiance and good service.  

I'm very sorry to say that we probably will not return.  Sadly, I have to agree with Katie V in that the food lacked flavor.  I feel that Athos, although more expensive, is a significantly better representation of greek/mediterranean food and flavors.

I think Moxie's is great, but it's also due to a number of variables besides the ice cream. The ice cream is also great - however it's not the best I've had* - but I want to ramble about the general atmosphere for a bit.

First of all, I love that Moxie's is named "Moxie's", which is adorable. I like that it's hidden about 3 miles from my house, on a street where you think you think you might be lost because how could there possibly be an awesome ice cream shop out *here*? I love the playground for the kids, which consists of swings and other equipment, but also a  wooden train for them to climb in and play in. I confess I can fit inside it too (hey, I barely reach 5'3").

Moxie's also has a "we're open, rain or shine" policy. Cool. When they first open around late May, they have  regular ice cream flavours, but as the summer season kicks in you'll find some wacky and interesting ones including their special of like, 5 different flavours of vanilla (actually - I was less impressed with this. A lot of the vanilla types tasted the same to me). I liked the Horchata or Fig flavour instead. Or Blueberry Cheesecake.

Go and get Moxie's, it's adorable and worth the trip and the ice cream is really darn good.


* that would be a tie between Berkshire Hills ginger ice cream (found in Williamstown where I work), and Christina's (found in Inman Square in Boston), for their Kulfi ice cream and followed closely by their Burnt Sugar flavour.

Alice's Diner offers homemade, delicious food in a comfortable, friendly atmosphere. But why is it just when you find a great place with great food, and think you could become a regular, you find out it's closing? On May 28, 2012, Alice's Diner will close its doors, and if they don't reopen elsewhere, it will be a loss to the Troy dining scene.

As the name suggests, Alice's is a true diner. A long counter with chrome stools divides the food prep area from the dining tables. Neon accents, including a really great neon-trimmed clock over the door, give the place a retro feel.

We were warmly greeted when we entered on a Sunday morning, and invited to sit wherever we liked. My husband ordered eggs over easy, home fries (which were really homemade and delicious!), and corned beef hash, a favorite of his that I don't make, so I'm always glad when he finds it on the menu. I had scrambled eggs, bacon, and French toast. 

You should know that in addition to being kind of a picky eater, I am most particular about my breakfast foods. Eggs have to be scrambled well, even to the point of browning a bit. Any soft/wet spots, and I can't eat them. Bacon has to be well done and crispy. Both were prepared exactly per my requests. 

The best part, though, was the French toast. I grew up eating it with cinnamon sprinkled into the egg mixture, and I rarely find it that way at restaurants. Most places usually opt for just shaking some powdered sugar over the toast, which is way too sweet for me when coupled with syrup. Not only does Alice's Diner use cinnamon, they add a bit of vanilla to the mixture. The result is absolutely delicious. I haven't enjoyed French toast that much away from home in a very long time, if ever.

For all the food we got, plus juice and coffee, not to mention the excellent service, our bill was less than $18 for two of us. More than reasonable.

As we ate, we chatted a bit with the owner and the waiter, who also seems to be the owner's business partner (we were the only ones there for a bit until a large family came in). They were very friendly, and explained the reason they were closing is that their landlord has already raised the rent twice in the year the diner has been at its present location, and was planning on raising it yet again. They've decided to close instead, when their lease runs out on May 28, 2012.

It's a shame because I could easily see us returning for breakfast on a regular basis, and probably trying it out for lunch, too. (I'm not sure if they're open for dinner). They're not sure yet whether they'll reopen in another Troy location.

If you like simple, delicious, affordable diner food, and friendly, attentive service, make plans to try Alice's Diner before they close. And if you enjoy it as much as we did, ask them to consider opening somewhere else in Troy so we can all continue to enjoy it. Looks like the spot where Uncle Ricky's Bagel Heaven used to be is still available...

Duncan's Dairy Bar is so good that the previous owners of a competing diner down the road hired an arsonist to burn it down. Fortunately the arsonist was an undercover cop.

Getting to Duncan's Dairy Bar takes a bit of well-rewarded initiative. It's east of Troy on the stop-and-go traffic of Route 7. They open painfully early and close at two p.m. The building itself is kind of ramshackle with afterthought add-on rooms. Like the majority of places in this area, not a lot of attention is paid to decor, but since moving here I've come to find this absence of any esthetic sensibility almost charming. Anesthetic, maybe? At any rate, Walker Evans would feel at home here.

A tall dining counter stretches across its considerable length, tables are plentiful, and even on weekends there's not too much of a wait. Although they serve lunch, Duncan's is primarily a breakfast place, and the food, while not nearly as innovative, is so good I prefer it by far over the Miss Albany Diner. Not to dismiss MAD, but on occasion one's psyche craves the anonymous dining company of farmers and provincial republicans wearing clothing found two seasons ago at TJMaxx.

All the breads are baked by the Duncan family. The waffles and blueberry pancakes are, according to my GF, the best she's ever had. My ritual meal consists of their ham and cheese omelette, and no matter how much I try, I cannot duplicate it at home. It's almost perfect. Going here is a great first stop for a day trip into the Berkshires.

How do you know a good restaurant? 
A, Its in a shady strip mall 
B. It sits within 20 feet of a tattoo parlor 
C. It's a BYOB and there is a liquor store across the street 
D. It's not another pizza place claiming to have the best pizza in NY 

Normally it would be C, hands down. But in the case of Garlic Lovers, I may have to go with....all of the above. 

I pre-read the yelp reviews and my expectations were pretty high. I went with two coworkers and we stopped and picked up a nice bottle of wine. We started with the Mediterranean platter which had hummus, baba ganoush, taziki, olives, grape leaves and falafel. It was certainly plenty for three people. The pita's that accompanied were fresh and warm. 

For entrees we got the: 
Chicken Kabob - nicely seasoned but paled in comparison to the other amazing dishes 
Lamb Stew - Out of this world. Amazing flavor, the lamb was falling apart it was cooked so perfectly and was in a flavorful tomato based sauce with orzo. Mmmmm..... 
Shrimp Remoulade - Shrimp were cooked nicely and the sauce was very tasty and hit you with a nice kick. It was flavorful spicy not hot spicy if you know what I mean. 

Each entree comes with a salad and I have to agree with another reviewer that it was fresh mixed greens versus other places that give you this limp attempt at a salad. It came with a cucumber vinaigrette. Odd but OK. 

We opted against dessert because we stuffed ourselves on entrees but would return in a heartbeat. Tattoo parlor and all.

Love the decor inside. Lots of kitch, lots of low, warm lighting. 

The story goes that it's named after its owners - a podiatrist and optometrist. Footsy. Magoo. Heh.

So the bar inside is pretty well stocked, and the bartenders have always been very professional when I've been. They have drink specials, but most of all the customer service has been top notch. I wanted a beer that wasn't chilled yet, so the bartender bought me another drink until it was ready. 

Food-wise, they have some sandwiches and chips. They don't have a deep fryer or oven. I think it's one of those building rules - they're don't have a microwave either, and only have a top-down heating surface, kind of like a low-power salamander. Still, what they do make is made well.
I went with one of my celiac friends. After explaining that he couldn't eat gluten, the bartender went through the menu with him and helped come up with something he could eat. But it was slow and there was time for it, so I don't know how feasible that is when it's busy. Also, you normally order at the kitchen window. Not with the bartender. It was confusing at first, but whatever works, right?

Either way, a nice place to relax with friends. Or lose your husband for half an hour while he plays skee ball because it's only $0.25 a game (9 balls).

Gimme that smoked pig!  And gimme a pickle.

A this tiny little Polish Deli in Watervliet, one can not just get various Sausages but  Smoked Hams,  Head Cheese, Smoked Bacon's and various cheeses.  They also have excellent homemade Pierogies and  homemade 3 DOLLAR QUART PICKLES. 

After a trip here, you can head down the street and get some cider donuts at Schuylers. Worth the trip

De Fazio's is the best pizza by far in the Capitol Region. The crust is great, both chewy and crunchy.  The sauce is equally good having both hints of sweetness and spiciness. Most Capitol region pizzerias miss both of these marks.

DeFazio's is a reason to head to Troy. It is simply the best.

The only reason why this gets two stars is because we came from Muddy's karaoke night, which was possibly the most depressing thing in the world (arm waving during eclipse of my heart? I don't think so pal).

this place is next to an OTB, a CVS, and across the street from a Wendy's and an Audi dealership. Not the greatest place for a bar.

So you walk in. In the city this would probably be close to a dive, but it isn't because of the restaurant portion and the actual tableclothed high tables on one side. It's divided, you have back to back bars in the middle, which is awkward because I thought I was lookin in the mirror but actually you just are looking at whoever is at opposite bar. the right side has a set of booths for people to gather, and the left side, beyond some arcade games, has awkwardly placed tables and a dj booth in the back. This manboob concoction was spinning hardcore rap......in the most bland place ever. the crowd sucked, a lot of has been twentysomethings who for some reason didn't make it down to downtown Albany this night and decided go local, go latham, go depressed. We even bumped into two former co-employees from high school movie theater stint. It was sufficiently awkward. 

there were two women sitting at one of the tables. I'm not sure why they were there, because they looked like they wanted to shoot themselves. Maybe they knew the DJ. Maybe they heard there was treasure here. I don't know.

2 dollar coors light pints though.

Falafel - when it is good, it is good, and here it is GOOOOOD! 

Family and I went again Saturday, just as dinner service was starting. The sign on the door actually said closed, but we opened the door and were welcomed in by a professional waitstaff. 

It was our first time for dinner and we started with the falafel and hummus appetizer. Essentially a deconstructed sandwich that got us all excited about dinner here. 

My boys each had the lamb kabobs - tasty, tender, and hot. 

I had the eggplant routini - I wasn't sure what that would look like at a Mediterranean restaurant, but it was so good that I had to stop sharing as everyone at the table was eating it. 

My wife had a forgettable chicken dish, but that is her fault for ordering chicken at a restaurant. 

The only downside was the rice - it was just bad. Fortunately there was plenty of food with each dinner that we did not need it. Funny that the server never asked about it as none of us took more than a single bite - but oh well. 

If you have never been, don't let the stipmall turn you off.  And as you walk in/out you can browse the tattoo parlor.  We will be going back, and soon.

This place isn't the best pizza. It's quality is akin to what I remember from your run of the mill sheet pizza when I was a kid. Sweet, saucy, greasy. So, if you're not out to impress, and you want to just get "a pizza," then this is the place to go. I cannot neglect to add that the decor on the inside of the place is absolutely classic 1960s - wood paneling (?) included. This is defintley a to go place.

For ribs, it beats Dinosaur, its just fact. Owner is always there, always pleasant and really is helping out the community too. Its delicious, its a chicken and rib joint,  with an urban appeal. I love the place. Puts you in the mind of an old school Kennedy's. Those who understand my description will understand how awesomely delicious it is. It beats the Pig Pit, Dino, Giffys, and PJ's for ribs, its just that serious

I'm shocked that I'm rating this place so highly.  I waited for nearly two hours on a Friday night for a friend and enjoyed every bit of it.  I was watching the three flat screen tv's and listening to the music.  Great!  I didn't have anything to eat or drink until my friend arrived.  The Hefe-Weizen was delicious.  The chicken pot pie was really good, with lots of flavor, veggies and chicken.  The noise level is low to medium and I highly recommend this as an enjoyable meeting place to both eat and talk.

Amazing!
So many flavors to try. Blue moon, horchata, pistachio-cherry, the vanillas.  Takes me a while to decide which flavor to go with per visit.

I love this place. I tried lamb curry which is bigger dish compared with Lazze on central ave. I like both though. Oh the Indian ice cream is Soooo good.         They have some especially hot shrimp don't try! My friend just gave a lick and start sweating.

OMG, get the wings, get the wings, get the wings. Crispy, meaty, moist, and well-sauced. I had the medium or mild wings with a friend, and they were plenty flavorful. JUST GET THEM.

Also had some of their fries and gravy. The fries were fine, gravy was better than I thought it was going to be. 

They also had Old Speckled Hen on tap! The name alone is enough to get me to order it. It was $5 for a pint.

The inside is all wood. It's almost like someone converted an old first-floor barn or garage into a bar. Really cool. The walls smell like they've absorbed years of fryer oil smell. It is a good sign. They have practiced years of the fine art of frying here.

Friday and Saturday nights are usually packed with people and live music. Lunch times are much more relaxed. I don't know if they do happy hour or food/drink specials on random nights either. It's a really casual place, so don't feel like you have to dress up. But you wouldn't be out of place in a business suit since there are offices  in the neighborhood as well. The crowd is a mix of people ranging from bikers to yuppies, and bartenders are relaxed and know how to handle a lot at once.

Possibly the worst name for a pizza shop. Ever. Really. 

Anywho, delicious Greek food can be found here. Great dolmades, hummus, and pita. Big portions, and very fast delivery, too.

I'm giving it the extra star because it's homemade. I only get chocolate, anywhere, and it was very good. I have other preferences, which I've already reviewed. If you like variety and want to try unique flavors, this could be your spot, but only if you like long country drives.It wasn't really a swealtering day, but the ice cream was still quite drippy, even for the undersized scoops and cone. It's known for being a dog friendly place. I don't get the name (unless it's really their family name), since the Moxie's I'm familiar with is an upscale salon.

But... But... I want to like this store! 

Pros:
I was on a mission to find organic fruits and vegetables for baby food. They had plenty! Avocados, mangoes, pears, apples, blueberries, and so much more. I also like their chip selection. I'm so sick of garbage chips with all kinds of crap in them. The meat and fish cases looked really yummy. I just didn't have the energy to fight the lines.

Cons:
This store is so claustrophobic. You're constantly bumping into everything. You can get a cart but there is no room to push them around! Well, maybe if you were the only person in the store but, you won't be. This definitely makes it difficult if you have a baby with you. The store is anything but baby friendly.

The worst part is the check out! They give you a square foot to put all your groceries on. So check out takes forever and the lines just build up. Also, the cart from the person before you (and the people before them and the people before them...) all accumulate at the end of the check out. I literally couldn't get through. This is something they should address immediately! 

I will be holding my breath HOPING they build a whole foods or Trader Joe's in this area soon! Until then... I'll have to get a baby sitter to run out to Fresh Market.

Found this place not long before closing last week looking for something new. Read the reviews and am glad I did because this is a real gem that has somehow been under the radar in Troy for generations! 

There are two shopfronts adjacent to each other. One is for the deli/store, and the other is for the pizzeria. The pizzeria is staffed by a rabble of friendly and talkative young men who engage all of their customers and come check on them to make sure everything is to their liking. The owner also makes his rounds asking for feedback, and seemed very receptive to the suggestion of adding a couple of ingredients to their tomato sauce! lol. 

Pizza was quite surprisingly good. Crust was not soggy, held firm and crispy almost until the final slice! The owner with great pride declared that it was made from his grandmother's bread recipe. He is definitely onto something with that! Sausage made on premises seems to be their calling card. Quite delicious with lots of spices and not overcooked. The flavor is a little subtle however, so don't go crazy with the toppings or else you may miss out, and that would be a shame. 

This place is BYOB, so prepare appropriately. Wine and beer are ok when brought from home. 

This is it, best pizza in Troy.

I am going to keep this ridiculously brief. We just moved down the block from this place, so we walked up there tonight having read all the reviews, ordered a four-cheese with red sauce (it's normally a white pizza.) Everyone was so friendly and sweet to us. We took it home (we couldn't eat in because they were all booked up!) And we ate it.

I had heard all over that the four-cheese is out of this world. I mean it has gorgonzola, that's GENIUS. 

You guys I think I cried. You know the part in Eat Pray Love (the book, you guys, not the movie) where Liz and Sophie go to Naples and get pizza from what (by deduction) must be the best pizza place in the world, and it's so good they cry? 

I am sure I was feeling what they were feeling. I mean, we've eaten all the pizza in Troy at this point. This is a completely different echelon of amazing.
Five. Stars. 
Yes, I'm coming back. YES. YES.

I'll preface this by saying that I don't really enjoy being touched, had never gotten a massage before this one, and probably won't again. Frankly, if a friend hadn't given me a gift certificate for a one-hour massage for my birthday, I never would have gone. 

I was extremely hesitant and frankly nervous before my massage. I explained this to Gretta, the owned of WSM, and she was instantly understanding. She has a warm, professional personality, and reassured me that everything would be fine, that it was normal to be a little nervous, and that she would make sure I was comfortable. 

Of course, I have no other experience to compare this to, but I was instantly drawn to Gretta and felt reassured as soon as she began. I had a relaxing, comfortable massage, and it was a great experience overall. After I was finished, she brought me a glass of water and told me I could take my time and relax in a back room until I was ready to leave. 

Overall, a great experience, and I may even go back someday. Gretta and WSM is a great place with a comfortable ambiance, classy decor, and a professional setting. 

FYI: there is no parking lot as they are located in "lovely" downtown Troy. Finding street parking is relatively easy, but be prepared to do so.

I was not particularly impressed with The Fresh Market. Having been to other upscale and specialty supermarkets, I found this one to be a little cramped and scatterbrained. It's not quite a supermarket -- if you're the thrifty sort, I would not recommend making it your home base super market -- but it's pretty good for prepared foods and specialty items now and again. 

I did find the prepared items to be quite good and fresh, and was happy to see such a bounty of candy. It might be a place where I will stop if I don't feel like cooking, but I don't think I'd shop there on a regular basis.

First visit was on Free Comic Book Day and thought it was great. Went back a week or so later with a friend close to closing time and the owner stayed open for me when I was running late and didn't make me feel rushed. It was awesome! He didn't have to do it, but he did and that made him my first choice for everything. Magic,comics,etc.

Look... they make great pizza. Lots of differnt kinds. Always fresh.

 I stop in once/mnth when I go to the bank next door. $5 Lunch deal = 2 giant cheese slices with a 12oz foutain soda.

Only bad thing... the fruit flies near the fountain soda. Needs cleaning daily guys!

Located in the shopping plaza next to ABC sports and fitness gym. Across from Latham Ford.

Best ice cream in area. Burgers are really good but kind of cheap meat. The owner should know sometimes they shut the grill down 15 minutes early. He told me I can order until 8:30 pm on weekday. Ridiculous of the teen workers! I drive all the way out there and they already shut down the grill. Keep your hours consistent!

Definitely the place to go in Troy.  Great burgers, sandwiches, and entrees (the fish and chips are my absolute favorite), but the beer is as good as it gets.

Nothing better than a Brown's burger, a couple of beers, a few friends, and a relaxing dinner out on the deck overlooking the Hudson (not a great view, but who's complaining?).

Golf coarse is in great shape always. The coarse is priced right as well. Only problem is the pub is not consistently open. We plan to eat lunch there and when we show up it may be closed that day? Weird. But coarse is awesome. Great place to golf!!!!!
High quality antiques....I mean I literally want about five things in this store.  Low pressure atmosphere, a real gem.  Highly recommend!
Great atmosphere -- especially out on the porch. Solid food and good beer.

Wow.
As I wrote in some previous posts, it's pretty likely my husband and I will be relocating to the Albany area -- and I think eating at Karavalli sealed the deal.
We always hit up Indian restaurants when we go on vacations, and even in places with huge Indian populations, like L.A. and Chicago, we've never found a Kerala-style restaurant like this. It's amazing!

Being a little depressed from the selection of apartments on our recent "apartment-hunting" trip, we decided to take it easy one night and try this place out. They were really busy, but we nabbed the last open table. For appetizers, we had the potato bonda and the bhagari jhinga, which were both excellent - and really filling.
My husband ordered an Indian beer called "old monk" that he remembered fondly and hasn't been able to find anywhere in the U.S., and I tried the Indian Shiraz, which, surprisingly, i really liked.
For entrees, I had the Kerala Fish Curry, which was a spicy, rich dish with coconut/tamarind sauce. He ordered a prawn dish, but I can't remember what it was called. Both were excellent and we ate way too much of them! But we still decided to stuff ourselves at dessert by sharing a pista kulfi and it was amazingly fresh and delicious.
Yum!
The manager here was very friendly, too. 
If we end up moving to Albany, I'm pretty sure this we will be at this place several times a month...

A restaurant witty enough to present Buffalo Frogs' Legs is in itself worth five stars.
Okay, I googled. This idea has been floating around for a couple of years, which is still good, because this area is usually six to ten years behind the times. Huzzah!
Probably my favorite straight up coffee shop in Troy.  It's a nice atmosphere with good coffee drinks, decent food, and occasional live music, comedy, etc.  I wish they were open later, though

A place to get lost in!  I love to just hang out there (if I have lots of time!). Best part that the owner is always there and is very helpful. He has often been able to check a book's availability when I called on the phone. Many Shaker High required reading novels, which my kids needed by "yesterday"! were easily and inexpensively obtained there.

Went a couple months ago when our dog ate a bunch of dark chocolate.

Wait was reasonable, staff were friendly. Vet gave good enough advice although he didn't believe us and was skeptical about our claim of how much chocolate the dog had eaten. Services were reasonable enough considering.

Tosca has been closed, out of business, gone since September 2009. The owner/chef has flied for bankruptcy, moved on to work at another restaurant, the equipment has been sold, and the space is offered for rent on Craigslist as we speak.

Here are some related articles about the closing:

http://blog.timesunion.com/business/tosca-grille-owner-files-for-bankruptcy/18653/

http://www.timesunion.com/AspStories/story.asp?storyID=844517&category=BUSINESS

http://www.examiner.com/examiner/x-2256-Upstate-NY-Restaurant-Examiner~y2009m9d21-Taxman-shutters-Tosca-other-Troy-spots

I'm kind of obsessing over Poland right now. I'm actually headed there this fall and decided I should give this place a shot as sort of a jumping off point. 

Muza reminds me of someone's Polish grandmother's house. In fact, much of the decor is frightening similar to items left behind by my Polish great-grandmother. The paintings are the same style as one that now hangs in my grandparents' home. So I can only assume that it smacks of authenticity in that area. After my trip to the "homeland" this fall, I'll have to report back with observations on the culinary authenticity. 

Boyfriend had the meat pierogies, which he enjoyed although he wished there was more of a sauce to go with them. I tried the "Polish vegetable salad," which turned out to be basically a potato salad-type concoction made with diced potatoes and other veggies. We Poles aren't exactly known for our haute cuisine, but as homestyle, comfort food goes, this salad was weirdly tasty. I say this as someone who really doesn't even care for mayo. 

I had the golumbkies, which I really loved. The cabbage was perfectly soft and wrap-like with no toughness to speak of. How do they get it that way? Even when I try boiling the crap out of cabbage leaves, I can't get them like this. The meat-and-tomato filling was also really tasty and the portion was large enough that I took one home. Not bad for $8. I think our total bill came to about $20 and we were both stuffed and carrying doggy bags when we left.

As previously mentioned in another review, the sole waitress is the owner's daughter and she's a doll. I chatted with her about my upcoming trip.  She's never been to P'land herself, but her parents are, in fact, from there. 

Muza isn't going to wow you or cause you to experience a mind-blowing foodgasm. That's not what it's trying to do. Think diner food, Polish style. You'll leave full and content, with barely a dent made in your wallet. And really, isn't that what you want sometimes when you go out to dinner? Sometimes I don't need bells and whistles. And apparently, sometimes I just want to feel like I'm in my ancestors' living room.

I come upstate to Cohoes to help out with family stuff and when I do, Mick's is my quick food goto spot.

Great pizza. They really get the sauce right and know how to make a well done pie if you ask for it.

Their salads are good too. They're large and filled with fresh ingredients.

The subs are fantastic as well. The bread that they use is crusty but not overly tough or chewy. 

I"m really glad that this place is just down the hill.

The staff is friendly as well.

Place is a joke.  Overpriced trendy foods.  Rotisserie chicken same as Hannaford costs twice as much.  Produce?  What produce?? Aisles too small, but trendy shoppers like that.  Better off going to Wallmart's organic food dept.

The best pizza anywhere.  The pesto pizza on the whole weat dough is out of this world.

Let me tell you that I know pizza.  I grew up in New York City, I ate pizza every day for about a year.  I've lived in Italy, had every kind of pizza there.  I love pizza of all kinds, and I can tell you Defazio's makes excellent pizza.

I would rather eat lint than not have a Defazio's pesto pizza.

What makes Defazio's so good?  They make their dough fresh from scratch on premises: you can simply taste it.  The sauces, all made next door at the Defazio's deli, which has been around for decades - probably close to 50 years or more - are all made from the best ingredients the old-fashioned way.  And Rocky has a secret ingredient in the pesto sauce that, I think, gives it the perfect taste for pizza.  Ask him about it.

20+ years ago when I tasted the pesto pizza for the first time I was in love, and it has been an enduring relationship.  Whenever I'm in Troy I make sure I stop by.  I sing love songs to my pizza when it arrives, and I weep tears of regret when I'm finished.  The other pizzas are good, too.

Think I'm embellishing???? Try it.

The family and I came here for brunch while visiting for a wedding.  The menu options were fairly standard fare, but somewhat limited for breakfast.

I ordered the steak, egg, and cheese wrap - it was ok.  The steak was a bit tough and it was unremarkable.  The husband got eggs Benedict and they were ok, but once again, somewhat just average.  My step-daughter ordered a bagel with cream cheese (not toasted) and it came out toasted.  They fixed that quickly, but it was still a bit frustrating.

The place was busy since there was a street fair going on, but the service was really kind of disappointing.  I ran out of water, my husband ran out of coffee, the food took a while.  Maybe they're more of a lunch/dinner place.

Big Apple Pizzeria (formerly Empire Pizzeria) is conveniently located at the corner of College Ave and 14th St, across the street from the RPI campus. 

This cozy pizza place offers an impressive selection of regular and specialty pizzas by the slice, about 20 pizzas on hand (Pizza Da Vinci has a similar concept). The specialty slices are $3.00 a slice and are pretty filling. They have cheese, pepperoni, meat lovers, buffalo chicken, ziti alfredo pizza, Greek, Hawaiian, veggies, steak & cheese, and eggplant, chicken parm, and more. The pizza crust is very firm with a pizza bread texture and loaded with tasty toppings. My favorite pizza slice is the breaded eggplant with red peppers. The slices are heated up in the oven and come out quick.

Pizza is the ideal food for the hungry college student! I would eat here a lot and try every slice if I were going to school again. Back in the day for me, I had to settle for Hole In The Wall for much of my pizza needs during study time crunches.

Besides pizza, they offer calzones, strombolis, garlic knots, rolls, salads, wings, appetizers, subs, and pasta dinners. See the menu and prices at http://www.bigapplepizzeria.com

There's seating inside and outside seating along the College Ave side. This place is open pretty late until 3AM (Sun-Thu), 4AM (Fri-Sat) and 2AM during the summer.

RAD is accepted here.

Way better than Northern Lights. Oh, so so so much better.

They serve Brown's beers on tap. Drink prices are what you'd expect for a music venue, but not the $7 you'd pay for a small well drink at Northern Lights.

Also, props for holding several Troy Night Out afterparties - the atmosphere is fun and all ages. Really. There are young people, older people, tons of people.

The balcony is also great - it feels like you get a better view of the stage, almost like you are closer, but also while separated from the mass of bodies downstairs immediately in front of the stage. In one front corner of the balcony is a perch/cubicle-sized area for some kind of control panel. Lights or sound maybe. I dunno. There's a ladder that goes from that to the floor, presumably to make it easier for whoever is up there to get there and down if needed during a busy night. All I know is it really makes me want to climb it every time I see it. 

Their parking is also pretty great. They have plenty of it, and it seems to be pretty easy to find.
Great beer, great outdoor patio with river views :)

After seeing Think and D's and Ticia G.'s reviews of Spiaks, which is just down the street from the Purple Pub, I knew I had to review this place.  But first a little back story, most people I know either go to The Purple Pub or Spiaks, but never go to both.  My wife and her family have always been Spiaks people and myself and my family only do the Purple Pub.  Since we've been together, we've had to cross enemy lines a couple times for family's sake, but neither of us has every said the other place was any good.  In fact, I don't recall just the 2 of us ever going to either of these places, we just can never agree on which one to go to.

Otherwise, my review is pretty similar to Andrew J's - I've been going here for years and have always enjoyed the food.  The pizza and wings are good as well as the Italian dishes.  They also have some pub fare, so there are quite a few choices and you can usually satisfy everyone.  Probably one of the main reasons my parents always took me and my sisters there.

I walked into Spring Garden thinking it would be a good fix for some bad-for-you cheap Chinese take out. 

It was your expected greasy fare, but had almost no seasoning. Is it the location? A bad cook? I have no idea, but it looks so clean I really wanted... something. A little more oyster sauce perhaps? Something, anything, really. 

This is just so odd, it  boggles my mind. On a positive note, at least it wasn't super salty...

There are a few things here you shouldn't miss:
the yeast raised donuts: Ask for a box to put them in
the coffee - good stuff
the natural rotiserrie wings are about the best I've ever had anywhere

Yes, it's cramped and far too expensive to be a regular stop, but it'll stay in rotation until Trader Joes opens in August. Oh, and the wings.

I'm going to take Hoffman's as it is, since I don't have the burden of nostalgia to color my impressions of it, but instead am coming here from California where we had a number of really good family-oriented theme parks in reasonable day-tripping distance.

There are 13 "kiddie" rides (if you count the excellent if short train loop) and 5 (or 6? do Bumper Cars count?) "regular" rides, and they all pretty much look like they were dumped there by a traveling carnival in 1956 which forgot to come back and pick them up.

Which to us is a feature. If you buy the 25-ticket book, you pay $28.75, which works out to about $1.15 a ride for the kiddie rides or $2.30 for the "premium" rides. I compare this to "attractions" at various Family Fun Centers in the area that run $4-$6 for a roughly equivalent amount of entertainment, or the awful mini-golf course adjacent that charges $4.50 for the worst course in creation for kids, or $39 (plus parking, you pay for parking for some reason) per person, adults included, at Six Flags up the Northway, I say, this is a complete bargain. 

The rides themselves don't last that long, but if you're entertaining somebody in that 2-6 year old range, that's a feature. There's enough that you can make two circuits of the park for one 25-ticket book if it's just the kids going, and you don't have to use all your tickets on the same visit (although apparently you can't keep them until the next season, caveat emptor). There's no admission fee and as such you don't pay as an adult for the privilege of standing around watching your kids fly in pretend biplanes or whirl-a-whirls.

The grounds are small and a bit old-timey - no real places to go stretch out - and dining options are limited to the usual ballpark/carnival fare. But it's all very low commitment - if the kids are getting bored after 15 minutes, why, you can just go without feeling like you have to make a huge admission ticket "worth it".

As far as the vintage of the rides go, I doubt seriously your kid minds if they're all a bit old hat, and there's a certain charm to the old school nature of the place.

Here is your age guide for how things will go - your mileage may vary but I doubt it:

Age 2 : will be scared and probably limited to the train ride and a few others.

Age 3: will want to go on about half the rides, but do them over and over and over again.

Age 4: will want to do every ride but will poop out about 2/3 of the way through, but not before whining to do the Bumper Cars

Age 5: will successfully go through all the rides, insist on buying more tickets, then start getting cranky after you've been on two repeats

Age 6: will start to lobby to go on the "adult" sized rides but will consent to ride on the kiddy rides, and will start to stick to regular favorites

Age 7: will start to sneer at some of the rides as kid stuff but once you get them on the ride they will continue to enjoy them as if they were 3 again

Age 8: will be stuck between not being big enough for the bigger rides by themselves but now being too big or above the kiddy rides, and will be stuck awkwardly not sure what they want to do

Age 9: will be in full on dislike of the place, except for the bumper cars

Best Indian around, compared to Curry house, lazeez, shalimar, and a few others. Difference is you certainly pay for it here. Buffet has a lot of items you won't find at the others but not too big of a fan of the bufffet. Meals though here are top notch but as stated plan on shelling out $20 a person minimum. My opinion the one in saratoga is better too.

I recently received a massage from Nick - it was so relaxing, exactly what I needed after a hectic day.  After my massage he even gave me tips on how to reduce my back and neck strain. He was very knowledgeable, I look forward to my next massage!
The name fits, it's South Troy, what do you expect? Worst burger outside of a prison, assuming they serve burgers in prison.

My ex lived about a block away from this place, and when we were dating we probably came here to eat breakfast once or twice a week.  I have to say, for a coffee shop, their coffee was not very good.  Way too strong, almost with a burnt flavor--I think they aren't using the right ratio of water to beans.  Their breakfast food is pretty good, though they screwed up the order often enough that I began to expect it.  It takes awhile for them to bring it out.  The staff was usually pretty friendly.

If the coffee matched up to the great hours, atmosphere, couches and open mic nights this could easily be my favourite coffeehouse in Troy.

Sadly the espresso sucks. The staff is mostly unfriendly and they couldn't care less about making a decent latte. I've had much better at Starbucks!

Really, Troy has a bunch of much better coffeehouses if you want good quality coffee.

For excellent French-press coffee  - go to Oliver's Natural's on Fulton  (and if you want it iced, it comes with coffee ice cubes so as it melts it doesn't get watery - delicious)

For excellent espresso - go to MochaBlend on Hoosick St up near Walmart.

Super clean, generally fresh produce and good selection of meat and baked goods, prices here are generally cheaper here than other stores in the area.  

People seem to be friendly and lines tend to be short.  Never have I thought to myself that I would not come back.

Can get some stuff at Wal-Mart cheaper once in a while, but never worth it no matter how many times I have tried.

3 stars is just about right. The fish frys are very good, although I didn't like their chili sauce...it was more like relish, but there were a lot of regular customers ordering it so ymmv. Had a fish fry with cocktail sauce and tartar that was very good. The staff here just yell the food back to the kitchen help and they are always getting it screwed up or miscommunicated...comical, maybe that is part of the charm? I also had a hot dog and the sauce is sort of bland...I prefer hot dog sauce with a lot more flavor and kick. They also had carrot cake and cheesecake available...figured they had to be great...the carrot cake was a little dry. Go eat fish frys, figure out what you like on them and you will be good to go.

So on a hot and humid summer afternoon my husband, step-daughter, and I came here to play some mini-golf.  With a little girl who hates bugs and heat, we decided to give their indoor course a go.  

It's a black-lit area that's designed with lots of wackiness.  The floor is 100% concrete.  The lady who sold the tickets warned us that it was super difficult and we may do better playing outside, but there was no convincing a 7 year-old to do that.

The course itself was extremely challenging.  Playing mini golf on concrete is not my idea of fun.  It was good way to kill our hot afternoon in some air conditioning, but it definitely wouldn't be my first choice of how to play.  I give them credit for being creative with what they could do with inside holes.  The outside course looked fun and I definitely would come back again.  The extra star is for the friendliness of the staff!

Agree with the other reviews, except that the garlic they use on their crust is powdered.  I think it would make it loads better if they just fresh garlic it up in their butter and spread it on the crust.

If you're in the area and deliver to your home, I'm jealous.  I wish I could do that.  This place is comparable to DeFazio's.

When is a bowling alley not a bowling alley? When it's a bar.

There's a bowling alley that opens at a certain time at night. I think like, 8/9? But otherwise if it's open, it's probably just the bar.

The Illium cafe is definitely one of the best restaurants in Troy. I have been there on a couple of occasions during street festivals. . The cafe is a tad cozy but comfortable and welcoming. They have some extraordinary specials and the value is great. The dishes a very creative with a good blend of different flavors. 

On my first visit during the Victorian Stroll, I tried the corned beef macaroni and cheese. That particular dish was unequivocally  the best mac and cheese I have had in Albany. On another visit I tried my first soft shell crab sandwich, which was pretty tasty. The only negative was the slow service. I hope to return for a weekend brunch in the near future.

If you like sub-par breweries, this could be your place. Fairly bland poorly crafted beer and nothing remarkable about the decor. I would love to say more about this place but it is hard to add to the overall descriptor of 'blah.'

That said, the staff was friendly, and if I can remember correctly through a beer induced fog I believe there was a view of the water.

Let's talk some baseball.  I am no pitcher, but if Fresh Market was the opposing team, our team would pull off the perfect game.

Today was my first time trying the place out, and I was highly disappointed.  At first glance, the place looked welcoming and vibrant.  I was drawn to the salmon deal that said buy one get one free for 5.99.  I started to ask a question to the lady that came over about that deal.  "How much would I need to get to get that deal...." She cut me off with something along the lines of, I'm helping this customer, you need to get a ticket.  I definitely didn't act as if I was cutting in line, but she definitely made me feel like it.  The answer probably would've take two words: "any amount."  Decided that I'm not having salmon tonight.  Strike 1.

I then went over to try some coffee.  They had some samplings which was nice.  I was pretty satisfied with the pumpkin spice decaff, but not so much on the decaff.  I asked the lady if there was a caffeinated pumpkin spice and she snapped at me saying that all the samplings were out in front of me.  Strike 2

I went to the check out, thinking overall, my first impressions were really bad.  A $3.79, 4.99, 5.99 came out to be 17.49.  I was actually a little preoccupied with figuring out whether the cash register was wirelessly connected to the TV, so I took a look at my receipt as I was walking out.  Now I know tax exists, but I didn't think I needed to tip my cash register.  I wanted to talk to someone about my receipt because it didn't seem right, and I was charged for a 10.99 bulk item.  As I went back to a register, the lady incessantly said, "I am closed after this customer, please find another register."  I was holding my receipt and shopping bag, obviously not looking like I was going to purchase anything.  But that didn't seem to matter to her.  No customer service there.  Foul ball.

So I finally got someone to help me.  He initially said, the 10.99 was a bulk item. Then he almost tried to convince me that the 10.99 was for the coffee, but I said, no that was 5.99.  I usually don't remember prices, so that might've changed my mind.  And then he came to conclusion that she accidentally pressed the wrong button.  He gave me back the $11 in cash and said, "we'll call it even."  No apologies.  He wasn't rude, but it's nice to hear a simple sorry.  I mean think about it, that was 3 products I bought.  Most people buy a lot more, which makes the mistakes harder to check.  Strike 3, game over.

The ninth inning was the highlight of the game.  Let me tell you, it was no easy feat, but I have decided, I am not coming back here by choice unless management makes trades for better players or maybe a Joe.  I'll leave on a high note.  In hindsight, I feel like I lowered my standards for buying stuff from them because I don't just buy a product; it's also about the service.  I'm sure if they recruited Wegmans, their team would hit a home run.  That's probably never going to happen, so I guess I'll have to wait on 79 Wolf.  Please make that happen Colonie.  Thanks!

Very good pizza and wings.

We got take out the other night. I had a coupon (printed out from their website) for a medium cheese pizza and 10 wings for $15.99. 

I ended up forgetting the damned coupon and paid $19+ for my take out meal. My mistake. Oh well. 

I don't think they deliver. 

We will defintely order from here again.

Geared to the 3 year-old and younger crowd, but suitable for parents to watch, I wasn't too thrilled with this place a few years ago.  Although my parents remember this place as being rides for older kids, they were fair depressed when they found out how much things changed, when they took my brothers(9 years old at the time), and I there.  I mean, really...?!  Let the public know in the newspapers that  this place is really meant for those young generation kids.  The seats were small(and so was the admission to get in(FREE), it only costed us a few dollars to buy ticket books.  Each ride only took about one ticket.
