There is a picnic area there(in back section of park), but with a small number of people, we had no one else to talk to...was embarrassed and sure felt bad on our ride home.  

The only good things with this park was, for those not enticed, there's a ice cream shop just outside(literally park grounds, along with a Subway sandwich shop.  Maybe the advertising from yesterday should have been listened to after-all.  I won't be returning, and neither will my kids(if I should ever have any).

Best wings in the capital region?  I'm not sure yet.  I really like Junior's (Albany) wings and I've heard good things about The Ruck (down the way in Troy).  But, I'll tell you what, it doesn't matter.  Eat all their wings.  Simply amazing.  Crispy, large, and reasonably-priced.  

So now that you've came for the wings, stay for the amazing beer selection.  I'm a Mahar's regular and there were some beers on tap that i haven't tried.  I imagine they keep the selection fresh so I'm not going to bother listing what they had when I was there.

A final note on the location.  They're right across the street from plenty of parking and, while the place doesn't look like more than a neighborhood worker's hole-in-the-wall, it's really sweet looking inside.  Lots of wood, murals in the bathroom, and a classic dining room- bar room split.  

Finally, the service.  I was there about a half hour before closing and figured I deserved at least a small frown or extra foamy beer.  Much to my delight, the staff was very cheerful and inviting, even for a couple of latecomers like my friend and I.

Browns has become one of my staples in Troy when I'm looking for decent food at a reasonable price.  I like it because I can come here when I'm not-so-fresh after a softball game or volleyball tournament or come directly from work in my work clothes and it's equally comfortable.  The atmosphere is pretty casual but still pretty nice.  As a result, I come here very often.

My favorite foods from Browns are their Cherry Raspberry BBQ wings, soft pretzels, steak salad, and even their cheese board.  The food in general is pretty good.  They have a good variety of beers (though once in a while they'll run out of something, but it's not a big deal since there's usually a comparable substitute).  Service is usually pretty good as well.  They used to hold trivia here though I'm not sure if they do any longer.

They also have outdoor seating when it's warm out which is always nice.  The one thing I will say is that since it's in a popular area (for Troy), they're prone to long waits on a Friday or Saturday night.  But that's normal for a lot of places so I just factor that in when I make plans.

It's nothing fancy but if you're looking for good food at a resonable price with good service and a casual atmosphere, Browns is a good place if you're in the Troy area.

I went and saw Jason Reeves play here for $12 and the staff was very friendly. They have a balcony with tables lining the railing, and they have 4 long booth seats on the lower level by the sound guy with 2 long coffee tables. They also have a bar where 1 cup off beer was about 4.25. I thought the stage was a little high, but the place reminded me a lot of The Chance in Poughkeepsie which was cool.

I've been in for coffee a few times before. I've always thought it was on the slightly more expensive side of affordable, but not horribly so. 

My guy likes going here for their unlimited cup of coffee. That + free wifi is a good working lunch/time killer if you're in between enagements in Troy. But when he calls me from here all I can hear are freaking brass instruments in the background. Maybe turn the knob down on the dial a bit. I wouldn't exactly call this a quiet coffee shop.

It seems like they're not very good with a crowd. The Troy Farmers Market is across the street in the winter (Atrium), and it seems like a lot come over for breakfast here at some point. 

I spent about 5 minutes waiting in a line of 3 people this weekend. It didn't move. At all. There were two people on register who kept calling for someone who wasn't picking up their food. Or one would call, and the other would just stand there not taking customers. If they don't come up the first few times you call, let 'em wait and come up to you. There were several other staff members who weren't busy and it made my brain think "OH MY GOSH, HOW DO YOU NOT HAVE A SENSE OF URGENCY WHEN THERE IS A LINE???? " over and over. 
This is one of my service peeves as a customer. I don't care if there is a long wait and a line as long as it looks like there is an effort being made to get things moving. But no moving? No moving at all? I gotta go.

I didn't get the feeling I would be putting an order in any time soon, so I left and went to the Placid Baker around the corner. 

If you're pressed for time, you might want to chose some other place. My guy likes going there for lunch. He says they make a good burger. I'll give them another shot, just not when I'm on any kind of schedule.

Although I've gotta say, their slowness made me discover a delicious breakfast sandwich at another business, and now I'm less likely to get food from them as a result of their slow service. I think there could be a bit of streamlining on the operational front, as this is something that is relatively easy to fix for the future so they don't lose any more customers.

Great wings, really meaty, 10 are more than enough for 1 person, large selection of tap beer, ambiance leaves something
To be desired

This review is based on the Lunch Buffet.

Bombay Grill is located at Routes 155 & 9 in the former Toyko Sushi and serves up Indian, Pakistani, and Afghani cuisine. The dining room atmosphere is relaxed, fully carpeted with several tables (linen covered tables/plate glass surface) with flowers, curtains in the windows, TV in the corner, and light background music. A Lunch Buffet is offered Tues-Fri 11:30AM-3:00PM ($7.95) and Sat-Sun 12:00PM-3:00PM ($9.95). 

I arrived here on a quiet Friday afternoon around 1:15PM and had the Lunch Buffet with a basket of hot naan included. The Buffet had 15 items including the 4 sauces (raita, mint, tamarind, onion chutney), green salad, chana papdi chat (cold chick pea salad), basmati rice, vegetable pakoras, tandoori chicken, chicken tika masala, lamb korma, bhindi masala (okra), chana masala, aloo palak, and a hot sweet rice dessert. 

Most of the food was good and hot including the chicken tika masala and the lamb korma. Some of the food was lukewarm including the rice and vegetable pakoras (very dry). The food had the right amount of spiciness and flavors. The hot rice dessert with sliced almonds was pretty good and I had to have seconds! The service was good and my used plates were cleared and the water glass was refilled and topped off between trips to the buffet. 

Overall 3.33 STARS for the lunch buffet.

Fabulous food, fabulous atmosphere, fabulous time!

Went here for the first time since the new ownership and what a great job they've done with the menu. Talk about soups, sammies, and salads with twists...and homemade breads to boot.

Had the beef lentil curry soup and it was delish! Very hearty yet light and well balanced flavors and some thick toasted bread for dunking was very delightful.  After I had the turkey panini sammy on focaccia and it was delish especially with the cranberry orange mayo.

For coffee had the peppermint coffee which was nicely balanced with that little hint of freshness you can't put your finger on.

INside you can tell that it's an old historical building but they make it a quaint intimate cafe and it gives you that big city feel which is kind of cool

Service---very nice people, but not good at waiting. With the exception of the one guy (wish I could remember his name) who was absolutely fabulous, the waitress and the hostess were nice but didn't know the menu very well and they were slow. Don't get me wrong, I liked the not being rushed atmosphere, but the waitress took forever for things and she forgot silverware--twice, and she never checked on us to see how we were doing and i had to ask to hostess to correct my incorrect side order.

However, the food was so delish and the people friendly that I will definitely try it again soon.

I have been coming to Bodywork Professionals for about a year now and there is no place else in the Capital Region that I would consider going to for deep tissue massage and body work.  I have always received professional, courteous, and caring service from my practitioner and the owner.  

I recently referred my boyfriend's daughter here when she was having back pain from her vigorously active life style.  She was originally scheduled with one of the practitioners who is also a doula who had to attend a birth and couldn't keep the appointment.  The owner went through great efforts to make sure that he got her in with another practitioner and that she received the care and treatment that she needed.  My boyfriend's daughter went back for a second appointment and was equally as pleased with her second session.  

This is one of the few businesses that I recommend without any hesitation or caveat.

Excellent italian food at a local joint!  

I had the chicken parm lunch special and it was delicious!  It was just the right amount of food.  The chicken had the right amount of breading and melted cheese and I loved how the garlic bread was almost half a foot long.  I've been to a bunch of italian restaurants where you usually only get a tiny piece of garlic bread and you run out of bread before you've finished your meal.

For dessert, I got the buttercream gelato.  I think the buttercream flavor was a little too subtle for me, but overall it was good and satisfied my gelato craving.      

I'll definitely go back if I'm ever in the area.  Go check out this place out and support local food joints!

I really like this little place!

There were so many yummy flavors, from Mojito to Cajun Strawberry and Coconut Chocolate Chip. I chose Cajun Chocolate Peanut Butter and my companion chose Cinnamon with Crisps. Mine was very rich chocolate, real, salty peanut butter and a really intense AWESOME spicy kick. Not sure what spices were included, but it was great!

The Cinnamon ice cream was very subtle and old fashioned-tasting; not too overwhelming. People who like light, elegant flavors will probably enjoy this.

I had to give it 4 stars because the prices were kind of high--I got a kiddie sized cone (one scant scoop) and it was $2.95. However, the ice cream is homemade so I think it was worth the novelty. 

I will definitely be back for a taste of the "Roman Delight" (a spumoni-inspired flavor) as well as the white wine sangria! 

Oh, and I'll probably play on the swings, too! ;op

The only reason they are getting 4 stars is because they actually had the beer I wanted on tap, unlike the usual "sorry we just ran out" or "we've been out of that for a few days".  With a whiskey barrel porter raised high, Cheers.  

I know they have been trying to beef up their menu from usual pub fare for the last several years, but anything that I have tried has been ho hum.  The burgers and other pub fare are excellent.  Last evening, with my whiskey barrel porter (which was chocolaty, caramelly, a little smoky whiskey delicious smoothness), I had a burger with guac.  I asked for medium rare and I got medium rare (which is a huge improvement from before when burgers were always served a la hockey puck).  The sweet potato fries were nice and crisp but could have been served hotter. Almost $10 for a burger and $2 for the sweet potato fries is a little pricy for what it is.  Stick to the pub fare and avoid the attempts at entrees which they shouldn't even be trying.  

The waitress was okay.  It was a TNO friday and they were busy but she was not all that attentive and I don't think we would have had here attention at all if it wasn't for us being an assertive 3 top table.  I did not get the extra pickles that I requested and that made me very very very sad.  

I'll keep going back because I like the brew but always set my expectations low for service and know to avoid anything on the menu other than the pub fare.

I moved from a major Metropolitan area and I miss my Whole Foods and Trader Joe's. I notice that the Fresh Market almost stole the lettering font and color from Whole Food and the basic premious of the store...setup etc. 

When things go on sale they are in the Whole Foods range. 

Let me say that I do shop here for some things but other things are overpriced even for Whole Foods standards. I was very disappointed that there meats are so OVERPRICED. They aren't even antibiotic and hormone free minus the chicken which I do buy. I called to ask them questions about their meat and clearly they have NO CLUE what they sell. 

They can improve I hope because I really want to love it there. THey have some really unique fun things there such as their bulk,coffee and candy section. But they have a way to go.

Sure, they changed their name to "Big Apple" - but anyone who is anyone still calls the place "Bella."

This is the first place I want to go when I go to Troy.

Pro tip: best when coming home from a party.

Good authentic middle eastern food. Prices are reasonable, unfortunately the service is VERY slow. Call ahead or plan for at least 75 minutes.

The lamb is fantastic as is the hummus.

This place is awesome. It's actually called footsy magoos. They have skee ball which I haven't played in years for 25 cents a game. Haven't tried the food but I have heard good things. The interior of the bar is decorated quite uniquely and is definitely worth checking out.

I agree with all the great things said about Footsy's, and some of  the not so great, like the unfriendly bartenders, and one is the co-owner. Still the place is amazing, and feels like home, but one big problem... What happened to the great live music? The band that used to play there a few times a month has not been there in ages, they are so great and the main reason my friends and I went there, so come on you guys, be nice to the paying customers and get Chris Busone and his band back there!

This little dive is on a quiet residential street in Troy.  You'll probably drive by and and not even notice that it's there.

But the Ale House has the best wings in the United States, and probably the world.

This is coming from a chicken wing FANATIC!

Try a small order of their Award-Hot wings.  They're "holy shit" hot, but still have such an awesome flavor.  If you're within 100 miles, swing by for these crispy AMAZING wings.
Excellent food, free Internet, and friendly environment make this cafe a must stop when your in or around Troy.

Dinner tonight was mushroom pierogi from this place.  Yummy, yummy, for under 400 calories for a big bowl.

Also got some fantastic little Kinder chocolate bars for when those cravings strike.  

It's a nice mix of some hard to find items and the staff is very friendly.  I'll be stopping by regularly.

Although I'm a frequent patron of the Albany Daily Grind, I'd never been to the Troy location until last weekend. After attending our friend's art opening as part of Troy Night Out, we gave up on trekking to the other shows because of the increasingly heavy snow fall. We decided to warm up with some hot drinks.

Same coffee, same drinks, but the locaion is a far cry from the beloved Albany basement location. The Troy DG is spacious and well-arranged, and they frequently have live music. I wish I could somehow take this location and stick it on Lark Street. Now that would be ideal...

Went here last night and was very impressed.  My boyfriend and I don't know a lot about Indian cuisine and the waiter was very friendly and helpful, offering many suggestions and being honest about what we'd enjoy and what were the best picks for us.

We both enjoyed our meals.  Everything was flavorful and ample.  The portion sizes are just right--not super huge, but not skimpy either.  My boyfriend ate his entire plate, but I had a good amount of leftovers.

The location is not the best, it is kind of out of the way in a little plaza, but not awful.  The restaurant itself is small, but clean and welcoming.  Prices are fair, maybe a little on the higher side compared to other Indian restaurants, but fair with the quality of the dishes.

I went to this restaurant based on the reviews. True to the reviews, this is really the best in this area. Their Malabar Goat Curry and Goat Biriyani are really good. The buffet on weekends is also good, but is pricey compared to restaurant in Texas. 

I would definitely recommend this restaurant if you are in the Albany Capital region.

This is my one stop shop for most of my basic hardware and home and garden needs because I'm in and out of here in no time. There's enough parking around the building, which is close to the front door. Country True Value is not the cheapest pricewise, but most items are convenient for me to find. The employees are easy to track down and are very helpful in locating items in the store when I need them. 

Earlier this month, I ended up buying my grass seed here instead of at Home Depot because I couldn't wait around for the Home Depot  employee to use the forklift while it was pouring rain outside. Of course, I paid a little more here for the convenience.

Sometimes smaller is better!

I'm not much of a beer drinker but the Troy Pub (which I will reluctantly call Brown's for the sake of this review) was a very frequent hangout during my RPI days. I still go back on occasion when I'm back in Troy.

The food is pretty decent, they have a tasty vegan bean burger and their fries are awesome.
